question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
For me, this is clearly the right shift,
The boredom-slash-wild-drunken-fight shift.
It's been called D&D
("Death and donuts," you see).
Yes, there's nothing like working the night shift.
question_list.question: What is the nickname for the night shift in a store?

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
To compose a morose epicedium
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium.
question_list.question: How can one brighten one's torpor and tedium?
alternate_answers:
The limerick suggests that composing a morose epicedium (a funeral song or poem) can help brighten one's torpor and tedium. The limerick states:

"To compose a morose epicedium 
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium."

So the answer is that writing a moderately melancholy funeral poem or song can help alleviate boredom and listlessness, according to the limerick.

Compose a morose epicedium.
Craft a sad dirge, not too mournful,
Just medium, not scornful,
To lift your spirits, a musical medium.

question_list.author: proof
question_list.text:
Have a car and my clothes without fail
Outside of this old county jail.
It has only one fence,
 Which does not make much sense,
So tomorrow I'll scale it and bail.
question_list.question: what about the county jail does not make much sense?
alternate_answers: The limerick about the county jail mentions a person who plans to scale the fence to escape the jail, which is not a typical or sensible way to leave a jail.

Based on the limerick, the detail that does not make much sense about the county jail is that it "has only one fence". The limerick suggests this is odd, implying a typical county jail would have more than one fence to help secure the facility and prevent inmates from escaping.

question_list.author: Celia Warren
question_list.text:
Oh, don't throw your toys out your pram!
Yes, I treat all your emails as spam.
Hurt your feelings? Don't care;
I don't like you, so there!
Just accept that I don't give a damn!
question_list.question: Why do I treat all your emails as spam?
alternate_answers:
Because I don't like you, so there!
Your feelings? I don't really care.
Just accept that I'm cold,
And your messages, old,
Are as welcome as a grizzly bear.

question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
That damn call button jockey, room 9,
Is a pain in the base of my spine.
For no reason he rings
About minuscule things.
His sole purpose? To hear himself whine.
question_list.question: What is the sole purpose of the occupant of room 9?
alternate_answers: The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to repeatedly press the call button, which can be quite frustrating for others.
The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to ring the call button for no significant reason, mainly to hear himself whine.

limerick_list.author: Duncan Stevens
limerick_list.text:
A young student held views that were hawkish.
His social skills? Awfully mawkish.
"Golly, let's hatch a plan
For invading Iran!"
His Harvard rep: "Dude's kinda dawkish."

limerick_list.author: Giri
limerick_list.text:
The new distancing norms will apply
From today; we must not pass them by.
Let's, my dear, for a start,
Do our part, be apart
At home, too—no more love on the fly.

limerick_list.author: Robert Hatfield
limerick_list.text:
When you've sucked all the juice from the cane,
The dry bits of pulp that remain
Are known as bagasse,
Which reminds me, alas,
What relaxed-fitting jeans might contain.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
When their Ma's away, no-one complains.
Favorite dinners? It doesn't take brains.
I just take a quick look
At her cookery book,
And make stuff from the pages with stains.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Oh freight car, my solace abates,
For among all your boxes and crates
Lies my babe — so much pain
When she sneaked on the train,
And she left me in desperate straits.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Don't just stand in the rain soaking wet,
Your clothes dabby (and clingy, I'll bet).
Your whole outfit's too sheer;
I see stuff from right here
Peering back like a daring duet.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
I went out with a squid, who was late.
Was he cold? Was he damp? (Was he straight?)
Just a mollusc — and proud
Of his mantle — I vowed
To remember this word: chlamydate.

limerick_list.author: man from tashkent
limerick_list.text:
Avant-garde, avant-jazz, avant-mime,
Means the thing is ahead of its time.
  But these verses I write
  Are so nifty, they might
Be considered to be avant-rhyme.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
I'm in love. There can be no ambiguousness.
My mind spins, in its dazed whirligiguousness.
When we touch, it's divine,
So our lives I'll align
As I'm longing to gain her contiguousness.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
An etoile's something shaped like a star,
But two definitions there are,
As it means "a regina
Of dance: ballerina."
(Etoile is more artsy by far.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Her smile was concealing her guile
From the moment we walked down the aisle,
So I no longer carry
Our license to marry—
It's been dumped in the circular file.

limerick_list.author: alkahuna
limerick_list.text:
Due to Hamilton's slanderous slur,
He was challenged to duel Aaron Burr.
We know Hamilton still
From the ten-dollar bill,
Yet his killer's recalled as a cur.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Now you're working as one of our clerks,
You'll enjoy all our jobholder's perks.
You can buy our devices
At very nice prices:
To employees, the cost is ex-works.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Our Chancellor's taxing us dry,
With a relish he cannot deny.
Come next year's election
We'll force his ejection,
And cheerfully wave him goodbye.

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
And Don John is still seething with spite —
There's a break-up he wants to incite.
So he brews up a plan:
Let the friends see a man
Next to Hero's dark window by night.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Though she once had her act well together,
Momma's mentally under the weather.
Befuddled and flustered,
Mom can't cut the mustard,
And goes missing; best get her a tether.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
That this poem is good's my perception.
Disagree? Then without an exception
You will suffer my wrath,
So stay out of my path
Or you'll wilt from my sharp-tongued correption.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Orthopedists accept the convention
That doctors avoid making mention
Of humerus things
When your arms are in slings,
'Cause it raises a bone of contention.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The plural of Dr. is, yes,
Made by adding an s: D-r-s.
So then, Mr.? If I
Speak of more than one guy,
I should use M-r-s., I would guess.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The moisture continues to seep
Through our shoes on the links as we creep
Past the puddles today.
Golf's not easy to play
When the casual water's this deep.

limerick_list.author: Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
Atalanta was notably fleet
And insisted her suitors compete.
She whipped all those nominees
Until young Hippomenes'
Temptations contrived sweet defeat.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Perry Como — a voice that would croon
A pleasant, melodious tune.
He brought to society
TV variety
And songs, always ended too soon.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A continuing resolution (CR)
Sees those US politicos spar
Over funds to pay bills.
Add expenses? Cut frills?
Or perhaps pull the plug! How bizarre.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
I had bragged of my foot's immense skill
At controlling the rudder, until
My huge sneeze jerked the cable;
Our boat was unable
To finish the race. Bitter pill!

limerick_list.author: cauliflower
limerick_list.text:
Around me the Indians clustered,
As, full of bravado, I blustered.
But I trembled like jello
And turned sickly yellow
When a brave whispered, "Paleface, you're Custer'd."

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Hattie Phelps is well known for odd chatter,
Which evolves from Hg-felted matter.
Every crown of hers brims
With peculiar whims.
It's her work makes her mad as a hatter.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
'Round the gills he's decidedly green.
"You look sickly as hell," said Doreen.
"You've repeatedly said
I'm fantastic in bed."
(He's just learned that she's only 15.)

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
'Twas hopeless, but dogged Black Hawk
Defended the Fox and the Sauk.
At Bad Axe, most fell,
And as history would tell,
The "War" led to real-estate talk.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I want you to marry me, quick,
As our chemistries just seem to click.
Our biocompatibility
Should assure our fertility
(And a transplant if ever you're sick).

limerick_list.author: cauliflower
limerick_list.text:
"Does my liking agnostics seem odd?
Well, at least these folk don't give the nod
To beliefs that induce
Men, with me their excuse,
To slaughter each other," says God.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
When Lily and Daisy and Rose
Went afield where the wildflower grows,
Did they while away hours
Whilst gathering flowers,
Or wilt in the sunshine and doze?

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
There are songs that the DJs don't play.
It's the same old thing, day after day.
If those guys ever knew
There are album tracks, too,
They forgot. It's cliché all the way.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
He was bumped off the passenger list,
And you'd think he'd have really been pissed.
But the airliner crashed,
So he would have been smashed,
Or bumped off, or erased.  Now he's blissed.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
All's quiet on the ol' Western Front,
Where there's nary a whisper nor grunt.
But you'll hear mama snort
When she chugs a whole quart —
Gulping beer gets her loud, coarse and blunt.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Had a spat with your sweetie? A buss
On the cheek might not end all the fuss.
Kiss her well—in your arms—
She'll succumb to your charms
And there'll be nothing more to discuss.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Those darn four-letter words may have more
Or (though rare) fewer letters than four.
Such a word might occur
As a swearword or slur,
Used in contexts my mom would deplore.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
He runs averagely, not fast or slow,
With a moderate distance to go.
He's of medium height
And his weight is just right—
Not a star but your typical Joe.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn and speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
The bio instructor I'm dating
Finds heaps of hot compost elating.
This steamy affair
Of exposure to air
(Or aerating) deserves an R-rating.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Depressed?" asked my shrink.  "Feeling blue?
Try some bibliotherapy.  Do.
Read self-help — it can heal —
And then write what you feel."
"Hell, then why am I talking to you?"

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Spend the night with this sculptured physique;
Call me "Oscar," a star at his peak.
Not for certain—not yet—
But that nude statuette
Will be mine. Shooting opens next week.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Some Velcro has fastened each shoe;
But the loud rasp-like sound gives the clue
That what's been on Tom's feet
Has been tossed in the street
From his pushchair.  He is only two.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A beaver, a true-love believer,
Was attached to a golden retriever.
Though he knew that the dog
Couldn't chew on a log,
He just wooden't conceivably leave her.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My son Jack couldn't find his way out
Of a paper bag given the route.
This big dimwit can't do
Simple tasks.  With no clue,
Basic skills he knows nothing about.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The backup musicians are those
I don't notice at night clubs and shows.
The singer's a star—
So's the lead on guitar;
But for me that's as far as it goes.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach and mino
limerick_list.text:
At a party, a donkey's pinned tail
Missed its mark, landing far beyond the pale.
It was said to append
To a lass in South Bend
Who relayed it back asswards by mail.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
With his "Enemies List" keeping score,
"Not-a-crook" wasn't one to ignore.
One thing's perfectly clear:
In his checkered career,
Can't kick Nixon around anymore.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
When you're stepping inside of this cavity,
You will notice traditional gravity
Undergoes evitation!
A pure aberration!
Levitation will lead to depravity!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
There's no chance that the girl who'd begun
Singing Wagner would die in Act One,
Since if somebody'd killed her,
There'd be no Brynhildr
To tell when the opera was done.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If a substance is dauby, in theory,
You're probably best to be leery.
It's adhesive as hell,
Not to mention as well
That it's glutinous, viscous, and smeary.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Every year several swimmers will drown
In the rip tides that form near our town.
As they swim for the shore,
They're pulled back more and more,
Then succumb to fatigue and go down.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I used to compose awful verse —
Wordy sonnets, long odes, never terse.
But on switching my aim
To the limerick game,
All my poems got (became) a lot worse.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Brompheniramine maleate eases
The itching, the hives and the sneezes
That allergies cause
When the spring brings its thaws
And the pollens float in on the breezes.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
I've just booked a holiday flat,
And the written agreement is fat.
But the owner was greedy:
"Security? Speedy!"
So I sent him an arrha plus VAT.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Hey doc, how much time have I got
With this case of cyesis — a lot?"
"You have eight months to go."
I was thinking, "Oh, no!"
Till he told me I'm having a tot.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
In the coach we were scared—under stress.
With Dick Turpin it's wise not to mess.
When he pulled out a knife,
Yelled, 'Your cash or your life!'
I fired off a quick text: SOS.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
Seems that throwing elections is fun
For Ralph Nader, who's threat'ning to run
Once again in '08.
So I'm angry, irate—
That's how Bush got his place in the sun.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Let's smash antiprotons in streams
Against protons in similar beams.
This DZero experiment
Brings more than just merriment,
But data to sift through in reams.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
He says "CONsomme." (Thinks he'd sound gay
If he said, as I do, "consomMÉ.")
Well, as long as my groom
Won't pronounce it "conSUME,"
It's OK for our wedding buffet.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
At the gas station, patrons feel screwed;
As the prices increase, they get rude.
So they rant and they curse
As each gallon gets worse.
(People over a barrel get crude.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A grizzled old tomcat recalls
How he'd catapult over the falls,
Then go barreling down,
While he tried not to drown.
Little doubt that that pussy had balls!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
We've deciphered the code from the corps.
And the message reads: "Troops! Send us more.
We are now in retreat
On the verge of defeat."
It's that lack of clear facts I abhor.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You have heard, I am willing to bet,
No Balanta from your TV set.
Local churchmen have stated
The Bible's translated,
But reruns of Seinfeld?  Not yet.

limerick_list.author: metallel
limerick_list.text:
A credit derivative play
Is a bet whether debtors will pay.
It started with millions,
Ballooned into trillions,
And then all the banks went away.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Since I'm costive, I sit broken-hearted;
Seems my luck in the loo has departed.
I'm aware that a movement
Would lead to improvement,
But, sadly, I can't get one started.

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
What causes some starches to split?
Well, enzymes! But let me submit
A term, off the cuff,
For this starch-splitting stuff:
It's amylolytic. (That's it.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The price of your prize, when appraised,
As you might have surmised, has been raised.
So, now you're apprised
That the price was revised.
Don't look so surprised, or amazed.

limerick_list.author: neilski
Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Chilaquiles for breakfast...why not?
Last night, seems I drank and forgot
To bring food from the store.
Sí,  I'll chop; it's no chore
Turning leftovers spicy and hot.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
"On a chessboard — with ten by ten squares —
Stand all bishops, both kings and two hares.
Black's to move; you are white:
Is a checkmate in sight?"
"That's a problem for fairies — Who cares?"

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
If I were a young single lad,
Out to furnish a bachelor pad,
I'd get cable TV,
A big couch just for me,
And a bed where I'd act like a cad.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
In the Tour de France, cyclists may mope
As they work out the dosage of dope.
Will that hill be so steep
That their cycle shorts weep?
A clinometer measures the slope.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
See those tiny straight lines that don't taper?
They're called burelage, there on the paper
That's used to make stamps.
Forgers' ardor it cramps,
And makes toilsome their criminal caper.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
It was War of the Worlds on the air,
Cross the country inducing a scare.
It was really a hoax;
Orson Welles liked his jokes.
No, the Martians were not really th

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
It's with gladness I pick up my pen
To write limericks now and again.
Creativity rocks!
From my hat to my socks
I am gleeful — the happiest of men.

limerick_list.author: Bob Egg
limerick_list.text:
My even-toed ungulate's piggies
Help him run, walk and stand (but not dig). He's
A cloven-hoofed swine,
So his trotters (like mine)
Each consist of two stumps and two biggies.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
It's a unit to measure your gem,
Or the width of a tulip's green stem,
Or the length of a bee,
Not too big, not too wee,
'Bout four tenths of an inch: one cm.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Here's a plant you will find where it's sandy;
To prevent dune erosion it's handy.
It can live in a marsh,
Where it's saline and harsh—
To beach goldenrod, salt is just dandy.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
She's the champ! Many "hats" are now tossed—
Disarrayment ensues (at a cost).
In this chaos/disorder,
We wildly applaud her.
(For sure, my tiara is lost.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Benzopyrene a bloke might obtain
From the smoke of a coal-fired train:
Five fused honeycomb rings—
Polycyclical things—
Twenty carbons arranged in a plane.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
As her sitter was sitting her, sauced,
Little Sister was tragically lost.
As she'd wanted to play,
Cora wandered away.
Keen "Alack," for a lass was the cost.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
"FHB": whispered call at the snack
To ensure that the guests had no lack
Of the best things to eat,
Be they fish, bread or meat.
The translation reads: family hold back.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I have fetus in fetu. A mass,
Which my body itself cannot pass,
Has been growing in me;
My poor twin it might be
With no chance of surviving, alas.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
An athletic supporter is not
In the stands and applauding each shot
As the cheerleaders call
For protecting the ball.
It's a genital holder, that's what.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My mom thought the time apropos,
With me preadolescent, to go
Have the talk.  She said, "These
Are the facts of life..."  "Please,"
I chimed in, "death and taxes!  I know!"

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Do my oddly cut flagstones, and craving
For haphazard forms, mean I'm raving?
Whereas Sylvia Plath
Paved with death her sad path,
I obsessively lay crazy paving.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"Mum, what's algeny?"  "Sonny, it means
Engineering, genetic. To genes,
It's what alchemy is
To the chemicals biz.
Enough questions for now. Eat your greens."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The contract you wrote's full of flaws.
I'm confused—it has given me pause.
Though I'll give it a try
I am not sure that I
Can accept the insanity clause.

limerick_list.author: Wattlebird
limerick_list.text:
Cowichan sweaters were great,
Heavy-knit and well patterned, their trait.
Unique in their form,
The raw wool made them warm.
Got a used one for Christmas.  First rate!

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
Amigo, you see this barranca?
It's like in the film Casablanca
When the Laszlo-caused rift
Left the hero (Rick) miffed.
Now he's drinking — I'll bet it ain't Sanka.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
A dowager duchess, quite grand,
Inherited oodles of land.
How she used to survive
While the duke was alive
Is a thing she can not understand.

limerick_list.author: Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
On a turtle, four elephants stand;
On their backs sits a marvelous land
With fantastical folks
And the funniest jokes—
It's the Discworld, and isn't it grand?

limerick_list.author: Bob Colonna
limerick_list.text:
A brannigan is a melee,
A squabble, a brawl, or a fray,
A quarrel, a riot,
A public disquiet —
The rest you will find in Roget.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Brown or yellowish garnets are known
By a flavorful name of their own.
They may serve as a luller
For your babe. From their color
They're aptly called cinnamon stone.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Though he'd hoped that his tone would be amatory,
Sam's proposal seemed sharply exclamatory.
He yelled, "Marry me now!"
Bess said, "Don't have a cow.
When you shout like a lout it's inflammatory."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"When his nails got all twisted, he ranted,
And shouted, and cursed till he panted.
Though he'd seemed so ideal,
Neil revealed he's a heel.
Disillusioned, I feel  disenchanted."

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
We have ice bags and toe tags, galore.
Need examiners (medical)? Sure!
If your morgue's small in size,
Hire one of our guys —
Check the buys at the coroner store.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Check out what the wind just blew in:
Andy Gump of the fadeaway chin.
There are lips, there are teeth,
Then there's nothing beneath
But a fizzle of bone-challenged skin.

limerick_list.author: SusanL and Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
There's an entrance out back that I know,
So come quickly; together we'll go
And sneak in from behind,
As I'm sure you don't mind
A free seat for this fabulous show.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
You damn cowlick!  Just how could you be
Sticking up my whole life.  Now I see
That you still are a chore
To comb flat even for
The mortician.  It's not only me.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
When you proffer an offer of proof
That includes a conceptual goof,
Then your chances fall off
For a job as a prof.
They will think that it proves you're a doof.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I would love to collect blanc de Chine.
I would treasure each white figurine
Made in China, they say,
Long ago, far away.
It is porcelain fit for a queen.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Near St Austell, a plasticine dwarf
Sits and twiddles his toes on the wharf.
For his substance, he'd own
He'd prefer china stone:
Cease your longing for kaolin, Morph!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
An exigence, folks, just arose!
(That's a "most urgent matter" to those
Who prefer words more plain
And consider me vain
Just for using that big word I chose.)

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I need to ensure you'll remain
Close at hand, so I plan to detain
You awhile. I'm afraid
That your schedule's delayed,
So don't move, but feel free to complain.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Her defensiveness keeps you apart;
Use your wit, son — it's state-of-the-art.
Honeyed words will disarm her,
Beguile her and charm her.
You'll finesse your way into her heart.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
"Once, as well as the past tense of do,
Done meant 'very' or 'down' — 'kinda,' too.
Sometimes English seems foreign
To me — like Andorran."
"That's Catalan."  "Well, then, Urdu."

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
They are wizened, these features of mine.
Of old age it is clearly a sign,
And my mind's full of drivel.
I've started to shrivel —
As I crine, I decline, I opine.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
I'm so sorry to come off so brusque,
But you seem to be wearing a musk
That, when it is whiffed,
Signals: "Give this short shrift,"
'Cause it smells like a moldy old husk.

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
I benevolently  smiled at my daughter.
(She'd broken a rule, and I'd caught her.)
"Keep those tear drops at bay—
I feel kindly today.
Just this once, you're in warm, not hot water."

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Poor old Romeo can't climb the wall.
"Wherefore art thou?" hear Juliet call
From her balcony. She
Wonders just how can he
Get it up. (No, his ladder, that's all.)

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
An artiodactyl's a pig
Or a camel; some little or big
Even-toed kind of beast—
Says my uncle, at least.
("It's an ungulate, sonny, you dig?")

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
A bleach-out's a nifty technique:
Take a photo that's printed real weak,
Then just draw over top
With your pen.  When you stop,
Bleach the pic, keep the drawing—très chic!

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
A seed in a proper location
Withstands winter's hard deprivation,
Surviving till spring;
Then the shoot does its thing
In the process we call germination.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
My house has no flat roof, it's gabled
And a "monument". (So it is labelled).
The gable's called "broken"
(A classical token)
Which doesn't mean that it's disabled.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
He's a master at work at his trade.
Watch him anvil one more perfect blade.
It's a time-honored scene
As he hammers it keen,
But such craftsmanship's certain to fade.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Brecciation's the breaking apart
Of a rock into fragments, the start
Of a new brecciation
Through sedimentation.
It'd break a geologist's heart!

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
• These points are remarkably clear.
• There's no dense clump of writing to fear.
• Let me start a new line.
• With a blob there, it's fine!
• Have you learnt about bullet points here?

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
I am crazy about ambiguity,
The surprising denotive gratuity,
Like a layered haiku
Or the logical goo
That's mistaken for mental acuity.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Mariah hates Nikki? No matter.
The loathing draws slurs from the latter.
Are the barbs from Minaj
A deliberate barrage
Or just prattle and mere "Idol" chatter?

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
They undulate, surge, and they swell,
Those billowy waves, so pellmell.
Then you head for the rail
With a countenance pale,
And a vision of watery hell.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
Did you know that the Greeks coined a word
For reductions that reach the absurd?
When you're done being logical
Be apagogical!
Impossible not to, I've heard.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"This gravy tastes better than most;
It's so flavoursome ..." prompting my host
To chuckle and pour
Me a quarter-pint more
Of the juices that flowed from the roast.

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
Did you hear that my big sister Roma
Came down with a serous cystoma?
An ovarian tumor,
Benign, with a humor—
It's also called cystadenoma.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An astonishing babe passed me by
To lock lips with this hideous guy.
I was stunned as she pressed
His foul hand to her breast.
In frustration, I moaned, "Ay-yi-yi!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With the Age of Flight barely begun,
Someone said, "Hey, let's have us some fun
By proposing a prize
To those guys in the skies."
(They first paused to go fight World War One.)

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
"You will not never go," sister said,
"If you don't, you'll not wish you weren't dead."
"Those DNs  are not cool—
Did they tell you in school?"
Very sweetly replied brother Fred.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In the course of kids' normal morphosis,
Each one closes his ductus arteriosus
When he starts breathing air.
It should shut then and there,
Or the infant may show cyanosis.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
"I have ruined our dinner!" Mom cried.
Then she heard a small voice by her side.
"Just leave it to Beaver."
He snatched up a cleaver.
"You'll taste fabulous, sliced and deep fried."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In the old days, when records began,
Many bureaucrats used an aman-
uensis to take
Down each word that they spake,
Or a sonnet in praise of Queen Anne.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I know wood; though I don't like to brag,
I have read every carpentry mag.
As a vigilant reader,
I've learned that the cedar
Of Lebanon shows on its flag.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
Adorable?  Maybe you are,
But you're also too cutesy by far.
It's a saccharine show;
Better pack it and go,
'Cause I'm getting the feathers and tar.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's an order to fees you collect.
Get them straight 'cause they're bound to be checked.
You at first may earn bash cash,
Then later there's ash cash,
And more in between, I suspect.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
She's a looker—astoundingly pretty;
Jaws drop when she walks in the city.
And whenever she talks,
She's the target of gawks,
'Cause she's also incredibly witty!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Bed of roses? For Di, bed of nails.
Thus a modern-day fairy tale fails:
First divorce, then the dash
From pursuers, and crash.
Now we weep for our Princess of Wales.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
When dentists buccolingually speak,
That's their lingo for tongue and for cheek.
(Not the cheek that I sit on —
The cheek my teeth bit on,
Raining buccots of pain for a week.)

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
When my friend stole the Carta Marina,
I laughed like a happy hyena,
Not knowing, perhaps,
Scandinavian maps
Rare as that one would bring a subpoena.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
"Distributives?  Class, there are four.
They're determiner words — please, don't snore!
They are every and each,
Either, neither," droned Teach.
She makes grammar a bore all the more.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The facets you've ground can collapse
At the smallest of innocent taps.
A cabochon's assets?
The gem has no facets —
Or an infinite number, perhaps.

limerick_list.author: Virge
limerick_list.text:
An airhead's some enemy land
Where your air force has taken command.
It's also a word
For that bubblebrained bird
Who's convinced al-Gebra should be banned.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Not in church, this fine pair were wed secularly.
Though too small to be seen by us specularly,
When two molecules joined
A new compound was coined,"
Cried the chemistry prof, "bimolecularly."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I buy crap that old ladies crochet
And then sell it for twice what I pay.
My accountant agreed
It's a gold mine, indeed!
I've been making good money this way.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Aspersorium—holds holy water,
Not aspersions you cast on my daughter
With your slanderous talk.
She's a Phelps. Take a walk
To the church for forgiveness, you rotter!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
In an orchestra, two (sometimes three)
Clarinetists are needed, like me.
I'm elated, I swear,
To be named second chair.
To be first, though — how great that would be.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
This stand-up comedian's miming
Is hopeless. The metre and rhyming
Of his humorous verse
Are inept; even worse,
His poor comic [long pause—falls flat] timing.

limerick_list.author: Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
Though outdoors, all is covered in snow,
In my hearth, logs are softly aglow.
Let it freeze, let it storm—
I'll stay cozy and warm
By the fireside, with nowhere to go.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When I planned a career in cytology,
My roommate in college said, "Golly gee,
I don't know what impels
This obsession with cells."
Soon I'll tell him he owes an apology.

limerick_list.author: danmcgrath
limerick_list.text:
At Trafalgar, Lord Nelson was bold —
Cut the French line of battle, we're told.
But while walking his deck,
Caught a slug in the neck.
Now he's dead, on his column, and cold.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If I name a particular date,
Calendarial seems like a straight-
forward way to express it.
Calendric? I guess it
Will do; it's confusion I hate!

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Take the hump, on today of all days?
On World Camel Day — be full of praise
For that fine desert mammal
The fatty-humped camel,
Of even-toed ungulate ways.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
A tree-dwelling panda perceives
That the bagworm, a moth larva, weaves
A silk casing that's strewn
With small twigs; a platoon
In his tree likes to eat shoots and leaves.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq and Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
The king was upset, his face red;
Close-enguarded (protected), he said,
"There's a stench in the air!
For our guards, we declare
A new law: Loose a fart? Lose a head."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The Negroes refuse to be cowed
As they struggle for freedom, unbowed.
They give voice to their blackness
And sharp-as-a-tackness
By shouting, "We're black and we're proud!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm not used to my mirrored reflection.
My past has no trace of connection.
I'm dislikened (disguised).
My whole life's been revised
Since my entry in Witness Protection.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
They've been killed for their pelts, and methinks
Abject animal cruelty stinks!
But consider this worrier:
With God the first furrier,
Shouldn't all of His children wear minks?

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
My toe became crooked, displaced
Just by walking, unshod, while in haste.
Now I'm one crippled grouch
While confined to the couch
As my toes, in some tape, are encased.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My gall bladder's filling with stones.
When one passes, you'll hear all my groans;
And if one should obstruct
In my biliary duct,
I'll be jaundiced in yellow-green tones.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I've been planning on getting away,
But my flight has been cancelled today.
Now this offer of eight
Thousand air miles is great,
But I'd rather have moola, okay?

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
When I tear something made out of crepe,
I have one chosen way to reshape
What I've ruined. I swear,
Such allegiance is rare!
Yes, I am an adherer to tape!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
If your body's attacked, it presents
You an immunogenic defense.
That response happens first,
Then a following burst
(Anamnestic, it's called) will commence.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Here's some junk mail: a washing machine
That declares, "I get everything clean!
No more washing by hand!"
But the price? Seven grand!
I know just where this goes: file 13.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"That degreed education of yours,"
Said my father, "will open most doors.
Opportunity knocks.
You won't find many locks."
"Dad, hold on.  Not through mopping these floors."

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
My definitive clinical trial
Of Viagra against Spanish fly'll
Be run double blinded—
Though I'm open minded,
The evidence stands out a mile.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In psychosis, this syndrome attacks ya,
And you imitate me—echopraxia.
I sit down, touch my shoe,
And you sit, touch yours too.
When you do, it's adieu ataraxia!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
A girl had the hots for a guy,
But she had a big stye on her eye.
Disproportional to
This life's blip she went through
Was her feeling she wanted to die.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
When uptight and beset by alarms
Making worse inconsolable qualms,
I just set myself free
With a nice cup of tea —
Shake the stress which this sweet nectar calms.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
In the talent show, arguments tore
Through the judges, as acts took the floor.
When the 'ground-breaking choice'
Had an ear-splitting voice,
The whole nation was shocked to the core.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
They determined their lives worth aligning
As each for the other was pining.
It tugs at your heart
To keep puppies apart,
Especially with all of that whining.

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
I visited Egypt with Sam,
Who is normally meek as a lamb.
When we went to the Nile,
Sammy cracked a huge smile,
Saying, "Damn!  Aswan helluva dam!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
You declare I'm pure silver, with clarity,
And I'm golden (an odd similarity).
I'm your oxygen too,
Iron-willed—seems that you
Like to praise me with elementarity.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
As a country, old England's quite grand,
But there's something you must understand:
Our cuisine is quite plain.
On the whole, in the main,
It's a place where the bland leads the bland.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
He tried hard not to hit a high popper—
Instead he swung high for a hopper.
A fast ball hit hard
Caught the shortstop off guard:
A sweet grounder with bounce.  It's a chopper!

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
God help us poor elderly souls—
Mrs Jarvis has taken up bowls!
Her confusion on bias
Is certain to try us,
And she thinks that the aim's to score goals!

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
I ain't smart;  I just can't pass a class.
So, no schoolin' fer me — I'm an ass.
I'm in such a low station,
Can't learn a vocation —
I guess I was born to pump gas.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
"Go and ask for her number," said John.
"She'll just laugh, and I think she's long gone."
"She's right there! Try 'hello'.
She can't say more than 'no'."
"I'm afraid. Please stop egging me on."

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster and SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your coin must be real—yessiree—
Nero ruled back in 60 AD.
But mine's a disgrace,
With Augustus's face
And a date that says 20 BC!

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
A baby wagon (also called pram)
Is a carriage for baby boy Sam.
We bought such a carriage
Before our June marriage
And carted it home on the tram.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Air Force One, as an aircraft, is great
For the president and heads of state.
(I'm just guessing because
The plane I flew in was
Air Force Five Hundred Seventy-Eight.)

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
"'Ere, Nobby, just 'and me the gear,"
Says Pilfering Sid in me ear,
So I gives 'im the cutters,
An' now the bloke mutters,
"This bolt is 'ard work… somefink's queer."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Through the whole of the freshman semester,
Lester pestered my best buddy Hester.
Then she called him a heel,
Which hurt Les a great deal,
And the wound wouldn't heal—only fester.

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
Just when do you say one's diurnal
(As in a zoology journal)?
When one's active in light
And sleeping at night
(The reverse of a creature nocturnal).

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Clever kids are now put through a hoop
On TV, spelling words like recoup.
There is one pushy mummy
Whose letter-crazed dummy
Is forced to drink alphabet soup.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Conrad Bain played a great foster dad,
Who shared all the love that he had.
Todd and Gary found joys
Playing fun-loving boys,
But in real life their lots were quite sad.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
It is called a black book (not in praise),
Which with malice lists names so to raise
The ill favor of some,
And those files thus become
Shabby records of rancorous ways.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
These emperors tower over all
Where the blizzards relentlessly squall.
In the bleak August night,
Male penguins sit tight
On their eggs, heeding fatherhood's call.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
I was taken aback, I confess,
At our wedding, on seeing her dress:
Stunning white, with a face
Made of Nottingham lace.
And the best thing of all? She said yes!

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Why the hell is my agent so slack?
Seven times I've called! Can't he call back?
There's a call-back today
For that part I must play!
If I miss it they'll cast that jerk Jack!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Apallesthesia is sadly befalling them.
Cell phone users, I mean. It's appalling them,
Because here is the thing:
If they don't hear a ring,
There's no way they can tell someone's calling them.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
This guy's shirt had a certain cachet:
In large letters were DSFA.
"What's that stand for? Some brand?"
His reply: "Doesn't stand
For anything, Mac. Go away!"

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
On a ladder don't step on a crack
Or else bad luck is bound to attack.
And a sidewalk don't let
Cross your path—better yet—
Don't walk under a cat if it's black.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
zqms
limerick_list.text:
I've read Yorkshire has weather that's tough,
That the east wind they get there is rough.
Straight from Russia, they say,
There's no break on its way,
But the locals insist, "Fair enough."

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
At Lafayette Park they collided
While jogging. Once bruises subsided,
Their blossoming love
Gave a push (she laughs: shove!)
To the jeweler's where rings are decided.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I awoke in a sweat when I dreamt
That our priest was no longer exempt
From suspicion. Surprisingly,
I reacted despisingly—
Looked down on the man with contempt.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
There's a deer trail, well worn, through the dale,
And the deer use it often. A male
Sniffed the air, caught my scent,
And straight for me he went.
On the trail, like a deer, I turned tail.

limerick_list.author: Rods
limerick_list.text:
To use language that somehow will stun,
And inform or impress everyone,
State things boldly, with force,
And repeat them, of course.
Asseveration: it's what you've just done.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Let me make myself perfectly clear:
As emir, I'm the boss around here.
But I also inspire
(I suspect) the desire
To deliver a kick to my rear.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Acapulco: we're there by the bay
Sunning topless, when to our dismay
Some dude in a thong
Takes our picture (so wrong!),
Then he says, "I take Visa, okay?"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The OEDILF's an incredible scheme!
Here's a project to counter its theme:
I'll be writing an ode
To the name of each road
In the world—hey, a guy's gotta dream!

limerick_list.author: Taillefer
limerick_list.text:
End consumers are customers who
Use the things they have bought, like a screw,
Or the food that they eat,
Which the sellers will treat
As just part of the business they do.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Fertilization will follow, when fated,
After couplings divinely x-rated:
The old egg-and-the-sperm thing,
The dead-bunnies-confirm thing.
Expecting, for most, means "elated."

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
I escaped after bearing the brunt
Of his beating; my blood-covered front
Proved he'd hit me with force.
Name his weapon? Of course—
If I could; I just know it was blunt.

limerick_list.author: Taillefer
limerick_list.text:
The Flemings (they're Belgians) speak Dutch,
Which is spoken in Flanders as such
(Like in Antwerp or Ghent,
Where they may pay their rent,
And where French isn't spoken that much).

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
Iraq's current state is abysmal,
With its prospects of peace rather dismal.
Dubya started this war,
Yielding blood, sweat and gore,
And success odds quite infinites'mal.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Now that training has started, recruits,
You must take off your civvies—your suits
And your dresses and jeans.
Then you'll put on these greens
And of course, since it's boot camp, these boots.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
I shall DI-a-gram HOW this verse GOES,
So the PLACE-s to STRESS are all THOSE
That app-EAR here in CAPS,
Thus ex-PLAIN-ing to CHAPS
How to READ it, so DIFF'rent from PROSE.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
The matador waved his red cape
At the bull, and the crowd stood agape.
With a twist to the left,
Señor's movements were deft,
And the bull simply slipped through the drape.

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
The French do not last in my plot,
And the Africans? Rarely that hot.
As these marigolds drop,
The calendula's top,
For the English have not gone to pot.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Cap Franz, on the ship he commands,
Yells "All Hans!" when his man-of-war lands.
Though from manifold clans,
Every tar is named Hans;
So to call for "All Hans!" means "All hands!"

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
In Wisconsin's a town named Eau Claire,
Not far from St. Paul. It was there
My first love I last met,
But my plans were upset,
And I lost her. I still feel despair.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
There is Capricorn up in the sky!
In the Zodiac, where does he lie?
He's beside Sagittarius
And next to Aquarius—
He's a goat and a horny old guy.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Faecal matter may void from the gut
Through a sphincter that should have stayed shut.
Such incontinence can,
For a woman or man,
Be described as "a pain in the butt"!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Expansiveness: that's what our brains
Discern as we travel in trains
From tightly packed beaches
To desolate reaches
Of seemingly limitless plains.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The creature was caught in a snare,
Which assuredly gave it a scare.
It seemed friendly and spry
(Though it's usually shy)
As I freed this delightful brown hare.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Though the shipwrecked young couple idealise it,
He's a Spaniard; she's French. They don't realise it,
But the language that each
Tries to teach on the beach
Will be mixed when their grandchildren creolise it.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It's as bad as a bite from a Bitis—
Dressler's syndrome, a pericarditis.
The victim's oppressed
With distress in his chest.
As you've guessed, I'd prefer pneumonitis.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Good night, nurse!  What's the world coming to?
We've got problems way more than a few.
To save civilization,
The young generation
Must delve into morals anew.

limerick_list.author: Miss Mimi
limerick_list.text:
From coconut milk, I skim cream.
With pineapple juice it will team
For a piña colada
Sipped beneath a ramada...
Then, alas, I awake from my dream.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
You think lithic reduction's a bore?
When I'm at it, you won't hear me snore,
Though you might catch me knapping,
My hammerstone rapping,
To fashion an axe from a core.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I was duped: got caught up in a plot
To sell home building plots that were not
What my spiels had depicted.
Though charged and convicted,
My sentence was not a whole lot.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Court of honor: The leader and scribe
Of your troop are the ones you should bribe
On this prize-giving board
For a girl scout award
(But make sure all your alibis jibe).

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
There are markets left open to fill.
If we fail to expand, others will.
(I'll admit that I'm hopin'
For my post they'll open
A branch office down in Brazil.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It's an exquisite brooch, all agree,
Where its delicate beauty is key.
Someone asks, though, "But is it
Pronounced as 'exquisite'?"
Your choice—makes no difference to me.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Over time, changes caused by mutation
Produce an adaptive radiation.
Its outcome, besides,
Is that nature provides
For her species' diversification.

limerick_list.author: Gtmac
limerick_list.text:
A grapheme enthusiast, Marge
Loved units of writing. Beau Sarge
Thus cabled his beauty,
"O u r a q-t!"
And saved on the per letter charge.

limerick_list.author: Aliza
limerick_list.text:
My flowers must always smell sweet:
Lovely scents for my garden retreat.
I have no pressing wish
To sniff aminoid fish,
Or worst of all: indole — dead meat!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
From the first hated cockcrow of morn,
It's the season of harvesting corn.
Then all evening we husk,
Right from noon and through dusk—
So it's been since my daddy was born.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
Though the sea has the means to seduce,
This nor'easter was tough on young Bruce.
Until now, I'd not seen
A man's face yellow-green,
But his turned to a vivid chartreuse!

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Under wraps you've reneged from the start.
Laughed when dropping folks right in the cart.
But I'll soon stop your laugh:
Spill the beans—blow the gaff.
Yes, go public and tear you apart.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Artful painter of color and light
With his work, Debussy's such a bright
Shining light in the list
Of composers who kissed
All our ears, putting hearts all aflight.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Though the future is out of our reach,
A computer can model… a beach:
Mine predicts that the sea
Will rise two feet; yours, three.
 "Garbage in, garbage out" goes for each.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Bipartisan backing that's drawn
From separate factions may spawn,
Through joint analytical
Efforts, political
Will for a peaceful new dawn.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Though he mainly plays golf just for fun,
Harold's handicap's decent: half-one.
"I'll deduct one stroke made
On the second hole played,
Then the fourth, sixth, and on, till we're done."

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
He's a cellular telephone user —
A text-spelling thumb-bone abuser.
Those ring tones are cheesy;
That belt pouch! It's easy
To tell by his phone he's a loser.

limerick_list.author: David Franks
limerick_list.text:
The five-finger discount applies
To the price of a shoplifter's prize,
Unless praxis demands
He use both of his hands
For an item that's way oversize.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When her candidacy was announced,
The incumbent's machine quickly pounced.
It was loaded for bear
And had money to spare.
At the polls she was thoroughly trounced.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
To be continued... The bad guy's made bail!
When the serial picked up the tale,
I looked for the end,
Round the cliff-hanger bend:
It continued—the good guy's in jail!

limerick_list.author: Jim Vincent
limerick_list.text:
See these shadows we're casting tonight?
Turn and look at the source. What a sight!
The moon's more than half full
(Seems it's flaunting its pull),
And its gibbousness grants enough light.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A buttery battery bakery,
Selling me fattening cakery:
Calorie curious?
Angry and furious!
Scandalous labeling fakery!

limerick_list.author: SafetyDog
limerick_list.text:
As a cowboy of stair rails, he slides
From dawn until dusk.  He abides
The splinters and rashes
And tumbling crashes
On the banistered trail, as he rides.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Of Madonna, the pop star, it's said,
"She's a cabalist."  Don't be misled;
Cabalism's much more
Than an item she wore —
A royt bendel, a string that is red.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Effete and some terms far more coarse
Were used when I wouldn't endorse
An excursion to nab
Prizes soldiers call grab —
That is, loot that is taken by force.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Need a hand or some aid for your cause?
Try assistants who work without pause.
Every day 'til Noel,
Santa's helpers excel.
Let us praise the subordinate Claus!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB and Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
A caretaker works at the zoo,
Taking care of the grounds. When a coup
Gets a government felled,
Till elections are held,
That regime is a caretaker too.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"I converted the code to plain text,"
A decipherer said.  "Now what's next
Are the much tougher reads
Of the wants and the needs
Of a woman.  That's got me perplexed."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Two great movies they're showing today
At the Bijou — let's go right away!
"Double Feature — One Buck!"
OMG, we're in luck:
Lusty Ladies and Virgins at Play.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
When I gorge myself silly on meat,
With cholesterol I am replete.
I eat bacon and wurst
Till I'm ready to burst.
Even then, I continue to eat!

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
Schoolyard friends called me callous and more,
Teasing nicknames that once made me sore.
Since my last name is Kalles,
They meant no real malice.
Still, bearing this name was a chore.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
Whatcha doing back there, epiglottis?
You help us to swallow, Mom taught us.
Seal my windpipe behind you.
When trying to find you,
I gape like a hippa-mo-pottus.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
The pudding I'll make is quite humble,
Being fruit and a nutmeg crumb jumble.
Not quite pie, not quite cake,
It is simple to make
And is served up with custard: a crumble.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
The word dampne's so old; oughta toss 'er.
It means "damn" — and I am at a loss, sir,
As to why Webster's lists it.
One reason exists; it
Was used once by one Geoffrey Chaucer.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Do our rulers have ethical health?
No, they're mostly old geezers with wealth.
Was chrysocracy bred
In democracy's bed?
Were we sleeping? Or did they use stealth?

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
With the moon-silvered goddess in sight,
In potential, dianium might
Be an element yet;
Not to be, we regret.
To resolve the transition's a fright.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I'm a typist here, single, that's why
I can always: "I'm new here, so, hi!"
That guy's nice! My heart flips.
I'll glam up, gloss my lips,
Wear the tight, slinky dress I'd put by.

limerick_list.author: splendiferous
limerick_list.text:
If you program in C it is best
To compare with ==.
If you try to compare
With an =, beware;
You will probably wind up depressed.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If your adjective's ending in able,
But an adverb's more suitable, Mabel,
Hyphen-A-B-L-Y
Is the suffix to try.
Tricks like these will good writing enable.

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
You should have a contraption about
When your safe respiration's in doubt.
An oxygen mask
Lets that gas do its task;
A gas mask keeps toxic ones out.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Uncle Jock is carnaptious; he's like
A great piledriver hitting a spike.
His temper is quick
As a conjurer's trick,
And you never know when he will strike.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I engined son Bart's kiddie kart.
That new motor set Bart's kart apart.
But he crashed. My mistake?
Failed to beef up the brake.
The poor kid lost the race — but not heart.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Baby Susie is bored. I've no skill
At infant amusement, but still
Try a motorboat b
On her belly to see
If she likes my bilabial trill.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Across from my house, right before
The pub's soon-to-be-opened (locked) door
Stood the crowd, kept at bay,
Who assembled each day
To enjoy all they could (sometimes more).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
On my charger, I'll certainly gallop on
Till I reach my estate, and I shall upon
Coming home to my fields,
Boost my sugarcane yields
With the help of the herbicide dalapon.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
A new cook for the ranchers was got,
Since the last one's work wasn't so hot.
He could only cook stew,
And that tasted like glue,
So the old biscuit shooter they shot.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Easygoingness, yes, that's my style;
Since I really don't care, I just smile.
Not concerned or perplexed,
I don't fret or get vexed.
Life's a breeze, not a burdensome trial.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
My roommate plays sax, alto sax.
His saxophone drowns out my fax.
He plays all afternoon,
But can't eke out a tune —
I think it's just talent he lacks.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
You say Burma changed names, well ha ha.
Just you wait 'til I tell my ol' Pa.
Will we now have to crave
A new Myanmar shave?
Think we'll stick with the old, me 'n' Ma.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
A bold one he is, Liam Carney,
Chasing every colleen in Killarney.
He brags of his "kills"
And his lovemaking skills,
But the girls in the town know it's blarney.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Oh! You've slipped, tripped and flipped running faster,
So now you're in need of a plaster.
While you're flat on your face,
Though you're not in disgrace,
It's disgracia (that's luckless disaster).

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Any bonfire night based on disputes
With sectarian factional roots
Is a half-baked excuse
(Very often abstruse)
For a show that destroys and pollutes.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
My challenge today is to find
An oasis of calm in my mind,
And tomorrow, maybe
I will conquer the sea
In a bathtub — a boat of a kind.

limerick_list.author: Robert Schechter
limerick_list.text:
At my funeral, chant a sweet psalm
To console those who loved me and calm
Their grief as they kneel
By my body and reel
As they learn my last words:  "Don't embalm."

limerick_list.author: bearybp
limerick_list.text:
At the fruit grove, the farmers split hairs
Over when to best harvest their pears,
Have their cherry trees sprayed
Against bugs that invade,
Or the impact of currant affairs.

limerick_list.author: Jantine Bootsman
limerick_list.text:
A Brent is a goose in the cold
That flies south for the winter, I'm told;
But to us he's a friend
Who came north in the end,
With a heart that is made out of gold.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Abdominal pregnancy can
Be a danger throughout its full span.
When gestation's ectopic,
Unless you're myopic,
You'll work with your doc on a plan.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Most animate nouns you can touch
And they'll feel you, like cattle and such,
Or gazelles or musicians
Or pediatricians,
But pebbles or bricks?  Not so much.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
My wife and myself — what's the trick?
Sixteen years now, we've run pretty thick.
It's sure not her butt
Or the size of my gut,
But whatever it is — man, we click!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Irish writers? There's none with a voice
As distinctive as that of James Joyce.
Read his Dubliners tales;
Their allure never fails,
And among them, The Dead's my first choice.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Called Diospyros, "foodstuff of Jove,"
It's a fruit tree, of dyestuff a trove;
Young persimmons we mashed,
Pulp in cotton we cached
From which no-sweat sweats fabric we wove.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Exposed by the press and TV,
Celebrity never comes free,
And when privacy lost
Is the ultimate cost,
Who'd want to be famous?  Not me.

limerick_list.author: Virge
limerick_list.text:
My inner child dried up and died,
And my feminine side tried to hide
When I wrote, dry and boring,
My tome on exploring
That old armadillo inside.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Consolidative is the word
When you downsize your staff by a third,
Then assess every store,
Closing down one in four…
But that's business, or hadn't you heard?

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
Artificial — not natural or real,
Like a flower that's made out of steel.
Or Terylene slacks,
Or fruit made from wax,
Or some restaurant chain's hamburger meal.

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
I'm plummeting free and don't care:
Got a chute, so I'll tumble with flair
Till its canopy spreads
As it tugs on the threads,
And I'll slow as it catches the air.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
The stuff makes her feel high and mighty—
The water of life, aqua vitae—
Till they come to arrest her
With an alcohol tester
On Highway 13, in her nightie.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
I don't want to hear somebody say,
"The manager's been called away.
If you wish to complain
You may come back again,
But I'll tell you the same every day!"

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
His old wife was becoming a drag.
A young lover now sits in his Jag;
She's his bit on the side
That he takes for a ride.
Yes, his fancy piece! (Some would say slag.)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Through the thorniest thicket and bramble,
Risking bramberry picking, we ramble.
But it's tricky to pick it:
That prickliest thicket
Can cut to the quick—it's a gamble.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
An acquittance says, "This debt is done."
It feels like you lost a whole ton.
An acquittance can edit
A lien from your credit:
Kick back and relax—have some fun!

limerick_list.author: Errol Nimbly
limerick_list.text:
Evolutionists? Way off the mark.
They deny that T. Rex rode the ark.
Godless Darwinist pimps
Claim our cousins are chimps;
Call that "science"? They live in the dark!

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Though my eyebrows are bushy, the space
In between them's a non-hairy place.
This glabella (so called
Since it's smoothish and bald)
Is a central locale on my face.

limerick_list.author: PaperSpock
limerick_list.text:
If you're finding the world not fantastic,
And you're willing to do something drastic,
Be a brother and see
Just how good life can be
When all that you do is monastic.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Barely bearable hearing these two:
They're my forebears, named Smokey and Pooh.
One's a bear, he maintains,
Having too little brains,
While the other repeats, "Only YOU!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The shortstop was taken aback
And he threatened a legal attack.
"Congress passed ADA;
You can't toss me away.
I've got aviophobia, Jack!"

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
See the soldiers march past: brave recruits —
Glinting guns, stiff salutes, shining boots.
Our nation's great story
Is writ with their glory.
(A pity we call them galloots.)

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Can you see The Big Ditch? No, it's not
The Grand Canyon! Is that what you thought?
It's a famous canal
In an isthmus locale
Down in Panama, humid and hot.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With computers, I've come to accept
That I'll always be somewhat inept.
Buffer storage, I read,
And what came to my head?
"That must be where the buffers are kept."

limerick_list.author: Eredicus
limerick_list.text:
There once was a good man from Bree—
The invincible horse now can see—
To riddle, to cry—
My dear, please don't lie—
Oh, no! I must have ADD!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The name of this tribe made me squeal; a
Quick toast I drank down in tequila.
Now I've sent them a plea, "Uh,
Can your name, the Cahuilla,
Be pronounced so it's rhyming with Sheila?"

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
Flour sifted, eggs ready to break,
And the oven preheated: let's bake!
Mix in sugar and spice,
And some cocoa—how nice!
When it's ready, we'll eat chocolate cake.

limerick_list.author: Harper
limerick_list.text:
To Meg Beagle's skill I aspire;
Her artistry couldn't be higher.
Her meter's perfection,
And her predilection
For rhyming I greatly admire.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Once, a horse-racing friend said to me,
"I've four certs here. They'll win, wait and see."
Well, the first three were fast,
But the fourth horse came last.
My accumulator win? Not one p!

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
"Some folks may be short and some tall,
But they've all got a rectum," you drawl.
Though it seems far from plain, I
Know this about ani —
Some critters don't have 'em at all.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Jack's AWTF, the poor guy.
"That's "away with the fairies," I sigh.
He seems lost and confused
So this shorthand is used
To imply he needs help to get by.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The colorful life that I knew
With its fun and excitement is through.
What was rich and diverse
Will, for better or worse,
Be exchanged for the dullness of you.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Can you think of a policy dafter
Than scuttling good trade deals like NAFTA?
Offshore car-makers gloat,
"Xenophobic old goat!"
North American job loss comes after.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
"Hey, I've lost some electrons!" wailed Adam.
"You're sure," asked his friend, "that you had 'em?"
"Of course I am sure—
Why, I'm positive! You're
Gonna help me to add 'em, dear Madam!"

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The price I'll edulcorate more:
Give me three shares, I'll pay you for four.
Yes, this deal I will sweeten;
It cannot be beaten.
Agree, or I walk out the door.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
In my camp there's an oven that's Dutch,
But it's no good for baking, as such.
Set this tight-lidded pot
In the flames to get hot;
Pot-roast rabbit comes fresh from the hutch.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
It was clear someone doctored her drink
From its strong unmartini-like stink.
It contains now a slug
Of some foul date-rape drug
And a spoonful of Bosco, we think.

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
We are crop-ears, the work of my wife.
Yes, my pup and I share this in life.
'Twas not through aggression,
But pride of possession.
Ain't it nice to be knicked by the knife?

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
In the channel, beginning your voyage,
You will note, port and starboard, the buoyage:
A system of floats
For safe passage of boats;
To the fish, though, a source of annoyage.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
Economic geography tells
You of more than just rivers or wells—
Where bananas will grow,
How commodities flow,
Who attracts or with duty repels.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
As a name, plain tobacco mosaic
virus does sound to me quite archaic.
So acetyl... (plus later,
ending ...serine) has greater
Appeal—it looks more algebraic.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
Cape Coast Castle on Ghana's Gold Coast
Was a British imperial post.
And a profit was made
Through this centre of trade,
Though the cargo itself paid the most.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Invading Iraq was so lamia;
It brought the U.S. a bad namia.
No reason for liking
Preemptively striking —
It sure made a Mesopotamia.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
In a feedlot, close by the frontier,
A rancher stopped briefly to peer.
"There is something amiss.
Inside, Ma and your sis
Are gorging on corn with that steer."

limerick_list.author: Beverley Sharp
limerick_list.text:
Crafting limericks takes cogitation
(That means "thinking") and metric frustration.
To get out of this jam,
I think, therefore, iamb!
Won't these anapests take a vacation?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Piles of fan mail arrive at my door:
Letters praising my role as the whore
In that hit Broadway drama
Goodbye Yokohama.
Cheers galore—the crowds roar:  "Give us more!"

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
I tell of a man of Nepal, and a
Hindu girl (name of Kaarjal), and a
Pre-arranged night
When they'd meet: first of Chait.
Frustration was due to the calendar.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Water-management experts look on
As consumptive use strands every swan.
What flowed down through a mill
Can be swum upon still;
Irrigation's used up, so it's gone.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Certain baseball terms need some explaining.
One fielder's a gymnast by training;
Those skills are a match
For a circus catch, natch,
Which the fan base finds most entertaining.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I am sick of your cigarette butts
In the yard, you contemptible putz!
Wash the car! Comb your hair!
Reupholster that chair!"
(Lord, her cagmagging's driving me nuts!)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Crymotherapy? Sounds like this act is
A criminal type of malpractice,
But it may be the answer
To your dermal pre-cancer,
As freezing it off, it, in fact, is.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
I'm an English hill farmer who hails
From the beautiful land of The Dales.
When I'm there with a chum
I'll exclaim "Ee bah gum,
There's nowt like this in Scotland or Wales!"

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
These whales and their curious kin
From the depths have a falcated fin
On their back, and up front
Is a beak that is blunt.
Once the hunt caused their numbers to thin.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
By way of, you know, reparation,
I said, "Pardon my belch."  A sensation!
"I don't like what I heard.
Please don't use that bad word.
So much nicer to say 'eructation'."

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Rastafarians tend to distrust
And regard with disdain and disgust
Evil Babylon — those
They abhor, I suppose,
As they're wicked, corrupt, and unjust.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You're amoral? You don't have a code
That will guide you down life's bumpy road.
But immoral? It's clear
That you do have one, dear,
But despite it, your sins haven't slowed.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
It's a flu virus making me sick;
There's no way I'll get better real quick.
Fever, headache as well:
I am living in Hell —
I am sure this was sent by Old Nick.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Current assets are those one can sell
Very quickly. I bet you can tell
Those called fixed (also plant),
Are the assets one can't.
I believe we've defined these quite well.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
In the spring a pained Eskimo groaned
At the mound of foul birds he'd deboned.
Though his wife had no freezer,
It strangely would please her
To see not a tern left unstoned.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Come the kids, gaily hopping on Pop,
Doing belly-flop tricks 'til they drop,
Plopping ceaselessly down
On the top of his crown.
Once he's dead, they can finally stop.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
At the rear of the barrel's the breech.
Further back on the shotgun, you reach
For the buttstock, the part
That will buck when you start
Blasting buckshot at birds in that beech.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
A rose is a rose was a rose.
Something comes, takes the stage, something goes —
Great events long forgotten,
Ideas gone rotten.
The dustheap of history grows.

limerick_list.author: timothymh
limerick_list.text:
My LP became warped from bad care,
And the sound was too awful to bear.
It had gotten distorted;
A disc was imported
And switched for the one with the wear.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
What is current? The old currant bun
Shows some has-been in "vodka-fuelled fun"
On a "kinky sex cruise".
Are such tattered tales news?
Guess they photo-degrade in The Sun.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
There once was a man from Nantucket
Who went to the stable to muck it.
But those horses could kick,
And he wasn't a hick,
So his brain was enclosed in a bucket.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Frank was fastuous (arrogant, proud),
With his head held erect, never bowed.
When admonished: "It's naughty
To be extra haughty,"
He sneered and he laughed right out loud.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
There's a new kid in town, named CAT6;
Data cabling now comes with new tricks.
Ten times faster, it's true,
It can route your power too.
Old CAT5? Why, that's just for the hicks!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
My mad hatter, my love, has no trust.
She dismisses desire with disgust.
Should our passion start, she
Sticks a hatpin in me,
And that damn pin sure dampens my lust!

limerick_list.author: geniuswaitress
limerick_list.text:
A conga line's what people do
On a cruise when they've had one or two;
Blue-haired folks by the mile
Shake their butts single file.
Please—don't let this happen to you!

limerick_list.author: nevadaace
limerick_list.text:
Charles Aaron, a doc, studied pain
When appendixes underwent strain.
Aaron's sign, named for him,
Hurts so much; it is grim.
For most folks, it could drive them insane.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
In combat, when radar's bistatic,
It's stealthy, and therefore pragmatic.
When the transmitter's placed,
The receiver is spaced
Far away; it's a coup technocratic.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Your first day?  For your welcome, some facts:
You'll get fired the day you get lax.
I last week gave the hatchet
To goof-off Bob Cratchit —
Slack off, and you too get the axe.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
As each cabra and kid sweetly sleeps,
Chupacabra, the goat-sucker, leaps
Like a 'roo, though reptilian.
See goat throats vermilion
With gore, caprid corpses in heaps.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
A butt-toot in church isn't good.
It's an accident: that's understood.
Not haphazard with Bob,
Who enjoys playing hob
With his cannon-blasts slapping on wood.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
They moved to the burbs so they might
Avoid sirens and noise and bright light.
But it made the pair weep
When they still couldn't sleep
'Cause the crickets were chirping all night.

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
A knight put his armour to bed,
Left on horseback to paint the town red,
Got to town, and then chanced
On a foe and got lanced —
So now he's out painting it dead.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
You must think me a gullible guy
If you thought lame excuses I'd buy.
It's my leg that you pull
With an old cock-and-bull
Kind of story. It's garbage. Don't try.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Diazomethane's a chemical gas
That in labs is considered first class,
But it's toxic, explosive,
And also corrosive.
Would I like some? No, thank you. I'll pass.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
An alien came to her door.
"In search of new worlds to explore?"
She asked the strange creature.
It tried to beseech her
For Hallowe'en treats she'd in store.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I've been hit by a truck, and a suit
Has been filed by my lawyers—a beaut!
It's the best on the docket;
They've found a deep pocket.
I'll certainly win lots of loot.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My wife and I suffer from cenes-
thesiopathy, Doctor, a grayness
Of spirit. It's real,
This discomfort we feel,
Although no distinct organ will pain us.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Arab Spring stirred up folks, got them wild.
Many African people felt riled.
For too long being wronged,
Into streets masses thronged,
Bringing ends to their leaders reviled.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Her neighbour's a stock-exchange broker,
And he won't wager blue chips on poker.
Every day he works hard
To ensure that each card
He turns over will be one more joker.

limerick_list.author: Blind Pig
limerick_list.text:
