The Coal Measures were put there by God.
Carboniferous pride
Turned to coal far and wide
In the measures that dinosaurs trod.

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
"Brought to zero": that's annihilation,
And fillip can be animation.
My sister Rosetta
Thinks terms sound much better
With such academicization.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Charybdis, Poseidon's young daughter,
Flooded lands for her pa. "You'd not oughter
Continue," said Zeus.
When she did, he let loose
With a spell. Now she sucks and spits water.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
There is much to cause Britons to bellyache,
From rock cakes that aunts like old Nellie bake,
To taxes, to terror,
To nuclear pile error —
But, God, block your ears should their telly break!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Since having a serious scare,
I prepare all my speeches with care.
Comments extemporaneous
May include some extraneous
Thoughts that just shouldn't be there.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
When yer out on the booze with yer mob,
Ya should choose a mate:  "Who's Sober Bob?"
Whether straight, gay or lezzo,
Please do pick a deso
To drive yers home safely. Good job.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
When you look at this limerick, derision
Could result from poor viewing precision.
There is only one here,
But if it should appear
There are two, then you have double vision!

When you look at this limerick, derision
Could result from poor viewing precision.
There is only one here,
But if it should appear
There are two, then you have double vision!

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
I am certain our ties will not sever.
Will I ever forsake you? I'll never.
I'll be yours, you'll be mine—
Till the end of the line.
I will love you, my soulmate, forever.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A portly young belle, quite a jewel,
Strode the street as she guided a mule.
Her beau said, "Please ride it."
Said she, "Me astride it?
I say! How excessively cruel."

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
There were pillows from floor up to ceiling.
She dove in and her senses were reeling.
It is true she was married,
But the torch was still carried,
For his wit was just too damn appealing.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I'm in love with the guy; that's, in essence,
Why my face wears a strange luminescence.
When I meet him I blush.
See my countenance flush?
Now my cheeks show a rosy calescence!

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
The ex-dividend date is the day
When my oil stock pays off. Let me say
That damn stock'd be soaring
If Dems would stop roaring.
You tree huggers? Out of the way!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Lost my wallet; it feels like a curse.
All my money is gone, but it's worse
That no mugger or thief
Is the cause of my grief—
Seems I need a new clasp on my purse.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Your bed was uncomfortable, true?
And you noticed the crack in the loo?
This hotel is a hole
Since we feel it's our goal
To discommodate people like you.

limerick_list.author: lopey and Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
As a delegate termed apostolic,
You're a diplomat (largely symbolic)
From the Vatican. There's
More to deal with than prayers;
What they need is a real workaholic.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
This environment's dull and banal;
It's been sapping my elan vital.
Neither changing nor growing,
I fear I'm plateauing.
I must soar, or I'm bound for a fall.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The consumedly amorous Mimi
Turned our meeting from friendly to steamy
When she whispered, "Hey, hon,
Are you hiding a gun...
Or are you just happy to see me?"

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
In the '60s, as history states,
Voted up with the motoring 'greats'
(Built by Jaguar cars—
Known as one of their stars)
Was the E-Type (desired by my mates).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I hoped Lee would agree, but he doesn't;
I had thought he'd be sweet, but he wasn't.
I'm feeling so cross
I'd complain to the boss,
But that wouldn't be just, so I mustn't.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Distributions of errors, allotted
As normal ones, show, neatly plotted,
A smooth, rather swell shape:
The Gaussian bell shape,
At closer look randomly dotted.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
When I'm threatened, my pulse rate will rise
As my heart pumps blood faster; my eyes
Open wide at the sight
That has filled me with fright.
As I freak out with fear, hear my cries.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's dismal and dark, and the smell
Of the fumes from the sulfur repel.
Acherontic, this river
Is making me shiver.
What horrors await me in Hell?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A teenager, Billy Joe Brock,
The most car-crazy kid on the block,
Though he drives a jalopy,
Is safe and not sloppy—
His brakes guaranteed antilock.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Cockeyed Optimist is nurse Nellie's ditty.
(She's cute and vivacious and pretty.)
Then charmer de Becque
Turns her into a wreck
With his bi-racial kids — what a pity!

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
An array is a list, with potential
For many dimensions, sequential,
To store numbers or text.
You will never be vexed —
They are indexed for quick referential.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
If you think the word coupling sounds nice
And your mind links to sex in a trice,
Well, just get back on track:
It's a clackety-clack
Railway wagon's connecting device.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
Salamanders and newts get a kick
Showing off their Caudata leg trick.
Though their prospects look grim
When you lop off a limb,
A new one kicks in pretty quick.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
When a cute sweet potato (a tuber),
Betrothed to a peanut (a goober),
Found her two-timing beau
Shagging Ida (a ho),
She declared their engagement was uber.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
I have teeth, like the typical mammal
(A marmoset, say, or a camel).
Amelification
Denotes the formation
Upon them of dental enamel.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
"It's not music or rhythm; it's meat.
It's a part of a bird that you eat.
Yes, this drumstick's the calf
Of a chicken." I laugh.
"It's for munching on, not to be beat."

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
My messmate (my favorite commensal)
Has tentacles (very prehensile).
We dine upon orcs;
I use spades and then forks,
But an octopus needs no utensil.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
It's Jim's birthday; let's give him the bumps —
Once for each of his years. Come on, chumps;
If we each grab a limb
We can fling even him
Up and down, though I bet his bum thumps.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
My babe's got a long curvy spine
With her neck concave up; she's divine.
Well okay, she's a horse.
I still love her, of course,
That adored ewe-necked baby o' mine.

limerick_list.author: Rich Ristow
limerick_list.text:
Annexational aims for a land
That had plenty of oil on hand
Brought the move to invade
But no promised parade.
The results didn't turn out as planned.

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
"I smell, Mr Speaker, a rat!
See him form in the air"—like a bat?
"See him darken the skies,
But"—before he can rise—
"He'll be nipped in the bud!"—and that's flat.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
You're choleric: it's easy to move
You to anger when others think you've
Got no reason for rage
That one can't assuage —
Such tempers just rarely improve.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When you cauponize, always give thanks
To consumers who buy beans and franks
(Or perhaps wine and cheese);
Making money's a breeze!
And it's safer than holding up banks.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan Caws-Elwitt
limerick_list.text:
To blend is to merge or to mix
(Like how mashup auteurs get their kicks).
You make a collage . . .
Or merlot pinotage . . .
Or composites of various pics.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You host sock hops, but tell me that none dance?
For the next one, to make it a fun dance,
And avoid your next flop,
Put the "hop" in sock hop
With Abondance there served in abundance.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In our hearts Stephen Foster belongs—
A composer of beautiful songs.
Though today he's well known,
He died poor and alone—
That was one of society's wrongs.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
I once had a case of amnesia.
Where was I?  I think Micronesia.
I don't really remember
If 'twas May or November,
But I cured it with milk of magnesia.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Sprigs of parsley will garnish my fish —
It's a decorative touch — and a wish
To do diners a favour
By adding some flavour.
Once cooked, it won't flap in the dish!

limerick_list.author: Elliot Niman
limerick_list.text:
In baseball, four balls yields a walk,
And a twitch on a pitch is a balk.
With three strikes you are out,
But a powerful clout
For a homer will make the fans talk.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
"When the bishops and I disagree,"
Said the pope, "I invite them to tea,
Then refer the old fools
To the doctrinal rules
That establish infallible me."

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Dental formula: This is the way
We can show in a graphic display
How the teeth in a mouth,
Front and back, north and south,
Are set out in specific array.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
It keeps blights from attacking your corn,
Fixes babies before they are born;
So much more than cosmetic,
Engineering genetic
Engenders both plaudits and scorn.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Reelection potential looked grave.
Could he get something back when he gave?
Oppo dirt would be grand,
A big  gift in the land
Of Prez Z  and the home of the fave.

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown
limerick_list.text:
Though I like what my meadow has spawned,
All the cereal seems to be awned,
 Meaning, unlike the thistle,
 The wheatgrass has bristle
And hair on its flowers. (It's blonde!)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When you're slimming, your doctor decrees
There are too many lipids in cheese.
If you're bored eating peas,
Here's a hint that will please:
Try the food at Lo Fat Cantonese.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
House of Horrors? That's something I might've
Known well would have been an excitive!
A monster that day
Told my kiddies that they
Had plump tummies he might take a bite'f!

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Since I know cayenne peppers are hot,
I really don't like them a lot.
Though their juice burns my hand,
All my sons think they're grand,
But it makes their breath smelly, like rot!

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
"A  Braunschweiger sandwich again!
My mother must hate me!" cried Ken.
"It's liverwurst, grayish,
Tastes bad, not okayish,
I'll be good, Lord, but stop her. Amen!"

limerick_list.author: GeneralE
limerick_list.text:
A balloon might be shaped like a gecko
Now that lately they've gone all high tech-o.
Back when bandwidth was small,
The first satellite call
Was reflected from one known as Echo.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
On the sinuous ridge north of town,
My sweet prom date, Suzanne, doffed her gown.
With my ego inflated,
Impatient, we mated.
On that esker, we've since settled down.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The cavalry pulled in belatedly.
Grant hid in the woods and awaited Lee.
But Lee never moved rashly,
Unthinkingly, brashly.
He took every step calculatedly.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dreadnought was cloth made of wool,
That was used to sew jackets, cut full,
Or the garment itself
That you'd take off the shelf,
Stick your arms in, and give it a pull.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Genus Branta comprises wild geese
That range wide—from Alaska to Greece.
Honking brants that alight
On my lawn for the night
Are by dawn often resting in peace.

limerick_list.author: cecelia
limerick_list.text:
An experienced hiker from Kent
Carried dubbin wherever she went.
"Its tallow and oil
Mean my boots never spoil
In the rain, and sore feet I prevent."

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
The home of some animal—when
It's a big one—is sometimes called den.
It takes courage to beard
There the lions; they're feared,
Whether felines, or simply big men!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Lexicographers here had concurred:
"The entry we need for this word
Isn't birding. Instead,"
A wise editor said,
"The infinitive's simply to bird."

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
His cuttings are faster and nearer
Than his peers', and his rates are much dearer.
He can fleece a whole flock
By eleven o'clock.
Clipper Jones is the country's top shearer.

limerick_list.author: zqms and Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
Some smoke pot, and some others must booze;
Some folks gamble, bet fortunes, and lose.
It's a human affliction,
This curse of addiction.
I'm lucky it's chocolate I choose.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Bobby Charlton played football with Jack.
Jack defended, while Bob would attack.
They made England light up
When they won the World Cup
In the team that drove Germany back.

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown
limerick_list.text:
If a girl cannot rhyme, I don't need her.
I love books with poetical meter.
 Elegiacs are best,
 So it's time I confessed:
I'm an avid and Ovid book reader.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
They are cheques that you find at the bank,
At the counter in fact, and they're blank.
They're supplied with goodwill
And might well fill the bill.
(Oh, that's "checks" if you spell like a Yank.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Of a faucet I usually think
When I'm thirsty and crave a cold drink.
It's a heart-warming sight:
From the tap to my right
Cool, clear water flows into my sink.

limerick_list.author: sl8ofhand
limerick_list.text:
On a Japanese beach (on vacation)
I remarked on the brilliant location.
"Oh, yes," said the man,
"That is why I'm so tan.
Here it only takes one aprication!"

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
You lie if you say that I knew
About death camps. It's simply not true.
There were lives lost at Krakau —
And lots more at Dachau?
You're inventing this out of the blue.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
We called her a bag lady. Why?
Her skin was a baggy supply.
She had dermatomegaly
From face to each leggaly.
Non-recyclable, too. I could cry.

limerick_list.author: David Franks
limerick_list.text:
We needed some aggregate, stat.
Three-eighths of an inch or less—that
Was the specification
For size. In summation:
I'm glad that we had that nice chat.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Amygdala, home of my fears,
And also of laughter and tears.
This almond-shaped grain
In the core of the brain
Will remain enigmatic for years.

limerick_list.author: Jeter Coffee
limerick_list.text:
If you set out to make the world better,
Plant a tree, sing a song, knit a sweater.
The future ahead
Is just meaningless, dead,
When the present's ignored by a fretter.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
There are pea species, wouldn't you know,
That don't follow the old status quo:
When it comes to their pods
They will double their odds —
Growing some in the soil below.

limerick_list.author: alkahuna
limerick_list.text:
She opened a trendy boutique
Filled with fashions expensive and chic.
Her venture's location?
An outback sheep station
(No sales for the hundredth straight week).

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
For my upcoming trial I'll need
Help from one bonny lawyer, indeed.
Which says nothing of beauty,
Rather skill in his duty.
(But should he become she, I'll accede.)

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
My toddler's full diaper was droopy,
And from here I could tell it was poopy.
Now let's hope it's his mom
Who defuses this bomb:
I can't stand when they're sticky and goopy.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Charlie Mingus showed dignified grace
As he ran from home plate to first base.
He wrote "HIT!" in the dust—
On the baseline, I trust,
Since the letters were all uppercase.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
Freeing cats is so effortless when
You open the bag and all ten
Fly out screeching, berserk.
But it's ten times the work
When you stuff them back in there again.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Beltane is pagan desire
Made flesh: as the flames travel higher,
The May Queen parades
From the tall colonnades
With her drummers and maids by the fire.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
He says, "Foot-power counts for a lot
With the Singer machine we've just got:
Press the treadle, this plate,
Switching heel and toe weight..."
"I'm in stitches," (feigns yawning) "sew what!"

limerick_list.author: TrossL and Richard English
limerick_list.text:
I once knew a man whose caresses
Could charm all the girls from their dresses.
They'd start with them on,
But they'd quickly be gone —
How I envied that man his successes.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Aloysius is very ambitious;
A Yale PhD his fond wish is,
But his graduate thesis
Has many faked pieces.
His data are phony, factitious.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Hope his heirs don't expect to inherit
A windfall from sales of The Ferret.
I deem it a dud;
I consider it crud
And adjudge it to be without merit.

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
My lunch wagon meal was replaced
With home cooking; a much better taste.
Yes, I've started brown bagging;
To workmates, I'm bragging!
I feast while they eat toxic waste.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I ain't never bin aimin' to hurt you.
You know that I'd never desert you."
Clem's words were like honey,
But Daisy felt funny,
So still she hangs onto her virtue.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
To clean muddy boots at the door,
So one doesn't leave tracks on the floor,
Or for scrubbing the wood
Of a deck, we found good
Some rough matting (a bear, heretofore).

limerick_list.author: Colin Salter
limerick_list.text:
If you fail to use minnows to lure
The chain pickerel, you will catch fewer.
It's a fish-eating fish
(Not much taste as a dish),
Which a spinner may also procure.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Her singing grew faint—died away—
All we heard was the orchestra play.
"Seems her low notes don't carry,"
Said the critics of Shari.
"Let's hope she starts lessons today."

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
A phase-changing process that makes
Liquid turn into vapor, and takes
The more volatile share
Up away in the air—
Evaporation is shrinking the lakes.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
In Scotland my laddie (a boy)
And my lassie (a girl), with a toy,
Went to play near two cairns,
Having fun as two bairns
Would; they're kids—full of life, hope, and joy!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Foreign policy can be a killer, son.
Not a job for Steves Bannon or Miller, son.
Jared, be my first mate.
Helm our new ship of state.
I'll move Rex far away from the tiller, son.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
She's excitingly like Aphrodite,
Mighty beautiful there in  her nightie.
To remove it—she's shy—
Contraclockwise I'll try.
I'll remember "left-loosey, right-tighty."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
In the Florence Bargello, a chair
Has upholstery showing some wear.
There's a zigzagging stitch
Done in needlepoint, which
Has a 17th-century flair.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
A divorce leads to mass disarrangement;
The result of a couple's estrangement.
While wed, neither cared —
All they owned jointly shared.
A decree now demands interchangement.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
I lie here bare-naked: no pants
And no shirt. But then, softly, some chants
Fill my yet-unborn ear.
And the voices ring clear:
"Now let's watch how the doctor decants."

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
We have boots for those working outdoors
And soft slippers for carpeted floors.
Our shoes aren't expensive;
Our stock, comprehensive:
Even ice-skates for penguins on tours.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
"You've broken your record," said Keating,
"For repeating your asinine bleating.
Going 'round and around,
You're beginning to sound
Like a darned broken record, repeating."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Two disciples ensepulchred Christ,
Wrapped in linens quite heavily spiced.
My belief?  Then a guard
Didn't try very hard
To stop robbers who planned a Christ heist.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
I got caught in a fight. Wow, man—what a fight!
(When you're dissed like that, man, then you gotta fight.)
It got hot. It got horrid.
Bumped the side of my forehead,
And got a large lump on my crotaphite.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A letter that's common is ess.
When it's missing, it causes me stress.
This anxiety, rising,
Is always surprising—
My esslessness makes me a mess.

limerick_list.author: Damian Hey
limerick_list.text:
Borborygmus: a rumbling sound
In your gut — we just heard one resound!
It is rude to the core...
Should there ever be more,
We will shout "borborygmi abound!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
From the time that a corncob is born,
By sweet kernels adorned (proudly worn),
Grains are plump and contented,
Except for the dented—
The ones that you'll find in dent corn.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
I was lying one day in the sun
When my mother said, "Listen up, hon!
You apply cocoa butter,
Or tomorrow you'll mutter
You're burned from the sun. Quickly! Run!"

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
Country music and cowgirls both shine
From their two halls of fame, each a shrine.
Only these inductees
Are in both: the three shes
Are Ms. Walker, Montana, and Cline.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My aunt Cassie, a lass from El Paso,
In Paris posed nude for Picasso.
He'd espied her behind
And he'd made up his mind.
"What a find," he'd opined. "Love that ass-o!"

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Dad would give the cold furnace a kick
Till the ashes fell down. Then he'd pick
Out the best of the coal
Which we'd find (bless his soul)
In the stockings we hung for St. Nick.

limerick_list.author: kandabongo
limerick_list.text:
Awry is when upset impedes
Like a beautiful putt (into weeds).
It's when A's turn to D's,
Or (forgive me now, please)
It's a loaf filled with caraway seeds.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
We marched out of barracks at dawn,
And we'd hardly time even to yawn
Or to don a tin hat
When they bombed the place flat—
It's the officers' new croquet-lawn.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
As an aerialist, Kate's a humdinger.
With trapeze expertise, she's a ringer.
When I asked her one day
To a spouse-swap soiree,
She said, "No, I'm not that kind of swinger."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The cycle that Michael will like
Is more likely a bike than a trike.
His career as a courier
Makes him a scurrier:
Steadily Pedalling Mike.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
For chicken soup, first steal a chicken.
Then pluck it and wave it to thicken
A cauldron of water.
When finished, it oughter
Cure six Sikhs, seven Jews, and one Wiccan.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
You'll find that she's full of surprises,
Like her bra cups of opposite sizes.
View her right boob for free;
For the left, there's a fee.
And a tandem display? The fee rises.

limerick_list.author: sigg
limerick_list.text:
He explored and he drew back the curtain
On regions unknown or uncertain,
On peoples exotic,
On customs erotic:
The Captain Sir Richard F. Burton.

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
For musicians, a common bad dream
Is pursuit by a murderous theme.
Though they sprint, they, in vain,
Augmentation sustain,
And they wake (with a slow-moving scream).

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Now the end of his lifetime is nearing,
My grandfather's losing his hearing.
I say, "Hi, you ol' sot!"
Then I whisper a lot,
But such cheekiness isn't endearing.

limerick_list.author: Chris Howlett
limerick_list.text:
A laird wanting quiet and peace
Lived a pacifist's life in Dumfries.
So when enemies came
And surrounded his hame,
He beseeched the besiegers to cease.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
I have genes from both sides. Which is winning?
Like mum's distaff, I'm constantly spinning,
Just retaining the thread;
But dad's sword's overhead —
I'm incisive, and cutting, and thinning.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Stuff to eat, fried and served up at speed,
And called fast food, meets busy folks' need
For a snack on the go
As they rush to and fro.
Mind that fat, though. Addictive? Indeed!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Chef's jackets are made double-breasted,
A clever design that's been tested
To cover up stains
From cooking remains,
By keeping the dirtied side nested.

limerick_list.author: Margaret Ford
limerick_list.text:
Disestablishmentarianism,
To the Church, was barbarianism.
So, with power not scanty,
Priests sponsored an anti,
Which blessed non-contrarianism.

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
Asynchronous transfer mode sends
Little parts of some data one tends
To receive disarranged,
But the stream seems unchanged:
It's sent quickly, and seamlessly blends.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
The multiple choice seemed so trite.
He's the master of all: 1) Great light.
2) Created the world.
3) Thunderbolts hurled.
4) All a th'above.  Clearly right!

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Colla voce: th' accompanist's sign
That rubato or stretto's "not mine",
To not play what I read:
Let the voice take the lead.
Setting tempo's the soloist's line.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
In a quest for fresh food that's not fridgeable,
I climb from my sky-high dirigible
To a blimp that's nearby.
For one active and spry,
The space between airships is bridgeable.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Strong and sturdy, and lacking fragility,
This plastic is known for ductility.
I can stretch it out thin
Into yarn you can spin.
You will love its extreme extensibility.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
When King Charles wouldn't take off his hat,
Judges loyal to Cromwell said that
A refusal to doff
Meant they'd chop much more off:
Change his viewpoint from where it was at.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
A banana skin, which you unzip,
Is quite safe till you carelessly flip
It aside to the ground—
Moist and floppy, it's bound
To make someone go arse over tip.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
His athleticism made the girls swoon.
You could say they were over the moon
For this muscular jock;
Every week they would flock
To his games—not a one was immune.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A catamount couchant appears
On the flags of the French cavaliers.
It's reclining, head raised,
But the English aren't fazed.
Most guffaw—others break out in sneers.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
A teacher (of pre-school, I think)
Gave her adjutator  (helper) a wink.
"These children are sweet,
Though they give me tired feet,
But our paychecks most certainly stink!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
No matter what happens, come hell
Or high water, the hardships I'll quell.
The path to the moon
May be obstacle-strewn.
Ain't no thang.  I'm compelled to excel.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
He's loud, but he ain't got the goods—
All excuses, all oughttas and shoulds—
Brutum fulmen. The loser
Might bray like a bruiser,
But I doubt he'd break wind in the woods.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Cardiopathy's playing a part
In his troubles, and so is a tart.
His cholesterol's high;
Now this hooker says bye,
And he loves her. It's breaking his heart.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"When I gaze at her face, I don't know
What it is that amazes me so."
"Bet my chips it's her lips
That are red at the tips—
Top one dips in a sweet Cupid's bow."

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
An exponent is somebody who
Will profess his preferred point of view
In debate or tirade.
What's the point of his trade?
To persuade his opinion is true.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It's not in the Alps, like Montblanc's,
Nor the tropics, where people hunt conchs.
It's a part of our city
That can get pretty gritty.
Ogden Nash wrote "No thonx" to the Bronx.

limerick_list.author: MattMonitto
limerick_list.text:
Republicans gave him much love;
And his office was high up above.
But he mangled each word
And his plans were absurd!
He was awful, when Bush comes to shove.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The costlier choice is the one
Where you pay a lot more for your fun.
"I'm not buying the cow
When the milk's free," I vow.
Says her dad, "Son, I'm holding a gun."

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
If a crystal's anhydrous, its knack
Is to filch H2O, then to pack
It in holes finely set
So the powder's not wet.
Some change color when water comes back.

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
She drew raves in E.T. as a child,
But Drew Barrymore grew to be wild.
She took a big chance
With a desktop "flash" dance,
While Dave Letterman sat there beguiled.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
I thought I was doing alright,
But I'm stuck with this building, on site.
The boss says, "No ligging,
Grab a banjo, get digging,
You'll dance to my music tonight."

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Is a cryptogam some kind of code
Or a grave where a body is stowed,
Or a plant that's among us?
It's a fern, moss or fungus,
Reproducing by spores that explode.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Sweat, deodorant, spittle and pee:
That's a cocktail unwholesome to me.
Though the guidelines and rules
Make us chlorinate pools,
I would much rather swim in the sea.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A capable matador's cape,
Fully able to ripple and drape,
Hides the matador's sword,
Which the bull has ignored,
Getting gored in the other's escape.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
I had an old dog, name of Rick,
Who would play with a softball or stick.
Then we tried a new game,
But his docity's lame.
This old dog cannot learn a new trick.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
A bow tie that can spin? Fancy that!
Makes a change from my blue, silk cravat.
So here goes, let it twirl
And I'll pull any girl —
Well, I would, but the battery's flat!

limerick_list.author: Nan
limerick_list.text:
George Bush and Dick Cheney and all —
Their adventurist notions appall.
Even though they'll deny it,
The facts just belie it —
Good grief!  They're invading Nepal.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Since with coffee my pulse rate goes up,
From a tiny, wee cup I should sup.
Or maybe I oughta
Add milk and more water,
If it's served in a copious cup.

limerick_list.author: Engineer
limerick_list.text:
The dividend number's what you
Divide the divisor into.
"Now do your 'gazindas',"
The math teacher grinned, "as
Ol' Jethro Bodine used to do."

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
I like my potatoes al dente.
To cook them ten minutes is plente,
So they don't turn to mush
Or primordial slush
Like they do when you boil them for twente.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
A fashion-trend maven stopped cold
In her tracks when she heard it extolled:
"Brightly colored as canna,
It's what's hot!"  The bandanna?
Over ten million handkerchiefs sold?

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
Your demonym, that is, gentilic,
Describes where you're from: your idyllic
Hometown called Acrylage
(That perfect small village)
Makes you proud to be called an Acrylic.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
A discriminating thought (bear and grin it)
From Gramps: "Revolutions per minute?
They ain't RPMs —"
(Here comes one of his gems...)
"It's RsPM, dang it, now i'n' it?"

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
I derive just a scruple of pleasure
From knowing apothecaries' measure.
That three of their drams
Equal twelve metric grams
Is a fact I can tell at my leisure.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
"Barack eavesdropped, he wiretapped our phones."
So claimed Donald and all of his drones.
Will we see any proof
Or is this one more spoof
To deflect us to fantasy zones?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
We hear that a Blackhawk is down—
It has called from the center of town.
We'll send airmobile troops
In a couple of groups.
We're the Rangers, a corps of renown.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I am scraping and pounding a skin
To soften the fibers within.
Clearly, make no mistake,
I could use the word break,
Since that term is distinctly akin.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Ladies saw him and swooned: "He's so dashing!"
And the other men saw their hopes crashing
Like the waves on the shore;
But he's handsome no more—
The result of a jolly good thrashing.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
Though you do have a spine and you're smarter
Than the plankton-gourmand Tunicata,
The truth (this may hurt)
Is that you and the squirt
Both belong to the phylum Chordata.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
Incising a fresh avocado
Requires no skill or bravado,
But the slicing is rare
Of an alligator pair,
Unless "I welcome death!" is your motto.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Honey, how do I look in this dress?"
"I could care less."  "You couldn't care less.
Unconcerned to the max,
With an interest quite lax,
You don't give a damn."  "Sorry, but yes."

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
Analphabetism's his plight.
His eyes give him adequate sight,
But in bed with a book,
There's no lamp on the hook:
He reads just as well with no light.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
The Bible — it starts with the Word,
Then recounts loads of stuff that occurred.
And then Jesus was born,
Did His thing and was gorn.
And He hasn't returned — I'd have heard.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
An art house is where you will find
All those films of less-popular kind,
Like a subtitled drama
Of some lonely farmer
Who's Russian, or crazy, or blind.

limerick_list.author: HeuristicsInc
limerick_list.text:
If you want to have friends all life long,
It's important to do them no wrong.
If it's garlic you eat
(Or your breath smells like feet),
Chew some mints that are adequately strong.

limerick_list.author: man from tashkent
limerick_list.text:
A balloon rubbed against a toupee
And then pushed to the ceiling will stay.
With electrons all veering,
It keeps on adhering
'Til static charge passes away.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
In the crack in the rock, Climber Joe
Sought relief in the water's cool flow.
He fell in the chasm,
And now the stream has him —
He'll wash up in the valley below.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
On the seventh I picked up my wood,
Stretched my arms a touch more than I should.
As I swung from my pivot,
My club tore a divot;
To baff does the fairway no good.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
Bo's research paper, Tudor Beau Peep
And His Progeny, made the girl weep:
Seems the family line
Contained more than one swine
And a literal flock of black sheep.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
An ambitious young artist from Ware
Pulls his socks up and slicks back his hair:
"I shall get, at the Met,
The aesthetical set
To anoint me as Mondrian's heir."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If your bone structure's actually big,
And each bone isn't thin as a twig,
Then you're big-boned, it's true.
I mean others, not you,
You enormous gargantuan pig!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
It may take just a while till you get
Up to speed, so I'll wait and won't fret.
Though at first all may hiss,
Avantgarde works like this:
When we're dead, our work lives, you can bet.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Some synthesized silicate that
Can be honeycomb-channeled (walls flat)
Is cordierite.
Aptly coated, it might
Well be used as a monolith cat.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Our bozzler, I'm sad to say, drinks
(Yes, our own parish constable Spinks).
He'll go straight from a bar
To the back of his car
To catch 40 (or 400!) winks.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Discerpible once was a word
(Meaning "tearable") spoken and heard.
Over time, folks would switch
To discerptible, which,
It appears, is the one now preferred.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I warned you that something would happen!
Such carelessness sure does a chap in.
You wanted to snooze;
Now your free time you lose.
You just can't let your wife catch you nappin'!

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
My grandpappy likes his corn likker.
He claims it is good for his ticker.
At one hundred and one,
He has outlived his son
(My old man). Who am I then to bicker?

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
Some who write about Martin L. King
Seem obsessive: "Oooh, he had a fling!"
Biographers?  Hacks
Launching senseless attacks!
"I've a dream" to them means not a thing.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Your assertion's completely unfair—
A concoction as thin as the air.
So you say I'm perverse,
Pertinacious, and worse?
My response is a terse "Au contraire!"

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
An interesting part of biology
Is the science of growth, called auxology.
Like men's muscular arms
Or girls' breasts' swelling charms —
But the bumps on one's head — that's phrenology.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
My brake cylinder's sprung a slow leak,
And is staining the floorboards of teak
In my custom Rolls-Royce.
I suppose I've no choice
But to see my mechanic this week.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Your proportions are wrong — that's the issue:
You're dieting always and wish you
Were skinny.  Your plight:
You're in need of more height
To disguise all your adipose tissue.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Any slight should receive an apology.
It's a norm based on moral psychology.
Simple rules of decorum
(Ethics purists adore 'em)
Form a system they call deontology.

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
"See the sea!" said the films of Cousteau.
As a diver that man was a pro.
In the realm of the shark,
You would often find Jacques.
We admire just how deep he would go.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Do all back-seat drivers annoy?
No, I'm one—mine's a job I enjoy.
You may see me zip by
Because I am a guy
In the fire department's employ.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
A rather precocious young lad
Asked Mommy, "If Hell's for the Bad
And those who have doubted,
Won't Hell be too  crowded?"
Said Mommy, "Uh…go ask your dad."

limerick_list.author: Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
At the end of the old aqueduct,
A thirstyosaurus had sucked.
By the following dawn,
All the water was gone.
The whole lake in his tummy he'd tucked.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A loan shark named "Mad Dog" MacMurray
Was demanding his dough in a hurry.
I'm flat broke so, instead,
I just shot the guy dead,
Thus decisively ending that worry.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
An author, notorious crook
In the past, urges folks, "Take a look
At my life — how I've turned
Things around and I've learned
That it's best to live life by the book."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This movement's not merely a stunt.
We have differing views—let's be blunt!
But the outfit we're forming
To fight global warming
Is a left-wing and right- common front.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
The old class went by bus, a cheap charter,
To revisit our old alma mater.
There it was by the door,
English yew, as before,
With the sign stating Taxus baccata.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
To do cleaning, the woman comes Monday,
So my mom does the housework on Sunday.
"I can't have Bess gawking
At dirt! She'll be talking!"
So Bessie thinks Monday is fun day.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
We're divorced, and we'll never pretend
That our marriage was good at the end.
I hate her; she hates me.
Now we're blissfully free!
Truly, all's well that ends well, my friend.

limerick_list.author: AronKuppersmith
limerick_list.text:
Clever conchoids were drawn to untangle
The old challenge to trisect an angle.
Mathematically
It's a curve, fourth degree,
Whose equation plots points graphs can wrangle.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Early pregnancy changes the state
Of the uterine core of your mate.
The caduca's wall swells —
Endometrial cells
For the blastocyst now lie in wait.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Why my painted-on smile is a frown:
Coulrophobia's rampant in town.
All the people appear
To be living in fear
Since my circus is here (I'm a clown).

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A brachial break is alarming,
An accident common in farming.
A thresher can trim,
Say, a hand from a limb
So it's shorter—that's sorta disarming.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Cherophobia sufferers say,
"We get anxious when happy or gay."
Fear of gaiety? True!
It could happen to you.
Play it safe and get glummer today.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The commensurateness of your dress
For a bride, is a stretch, I confess.
Your taste's rather bizarre.
You have gone a tad far —
Just a skirt and a bra? No finesse!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
I've a sweet tooth real bad. Accolades
To all sugary treats: Cheers, parades!
But what pushes my button,
What really is cuttin'?
It's honey that's getting top grades!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My father's an oddball magician
And a man with a predisposition
For defying old habits:
He pulls hats out of rabbits
In order to break with tradition.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Told the cop that I wasn't Ed Cook.
It's not me in the day book — just look!
(But my chances are scant,
Though I rave and I rant.
DNA will soon prove me the crook.)

limerick_list.author: Janice M. Eisen
limerick_list.text:
Though for "am not" 'twas once a contraction,
Teachers ruled it an English infraction.
So we now, with a sigh,
Have to say, "Aren't I?"
Ain't it shameful, this overreaction?

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Wings of skin help dermopterans glide;
"Flying lemurs" they're dubbed (as a guide).
But dermapterans crawl,
Scarcely flying at all:
Earwigs' wings hide in cases of hide.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
Eating too much pâté de foie gras,
I have increased my avoirdupois.
All my kids tell me that
I am portly, not fat.
('Cos I bribe them with chocolate!  Voilà!)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Achilles had brains in his cranium,
But his failing remained his calcaneum.
Hit his heel bone? He's dead,
'Cause he hadn't, instead,
A prosthesis made out of titanium.

limerick_list.author: Kirk Zurell
limerick_list.text:
The finest achievement of man
Is candy, in bag, box or can.
It's food just for joy,
A flavourful toy,
And dentists' retirement plan.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
Said the chef, "My superb curry flavor
Is what helps, I have found, curry favor
With those restaurant scribes,
So, without any bribes,
Their reviews will be ones I can savor."

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
Full of joy, full of happiness, glad
Or gladful was Brad as a lad.
As an adult, however,
And not at all clever,
He thought that his life had gone bad.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Well, you might find your name in Izvestia,
But not for excessive modestia.
Reputation? Quite sunk,
Since you're often found drunk:
A notorious case of aplestia.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Take your grandson and just go away, sir!
Charlie won't win the chocolate!  You'll pay, sir,
For lifting-drink stealing
And a sterilized ceiling!
He gets nothing!  He loses!  Good day, sir!

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Ecumenicalism intends
That all Christians unite, and be friends.
Its proponents expect
Every heretic sect
To reject what divides and offends.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Said a gay to his ex, "You're a great man,
But surely you knew it was fate, man.
We've talked of our dreams
To form comedy teams,
But neither one wants to play straight man."

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Our guild, Gold and Silver Wyre Drawers,
Gets sniggers, not laughs (or applause).
But of drawing of wire
We never do tire
When precious. Now, how about yours?

limerick_list.author: GaZoom
limerick_list.text:
It's really not hocus and pocus—
Use some chemotaxonomical focus
On reactions to sleuth
Biochemical truth:
Have we buttercup, lily, or crocus?

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
Said Holmes, "Upon closer inspexion,
I deduce there is no real connexion.
That clue my devoted
Man Watson just noted?
Red herring! It's just a deflexion."

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
A dead body does differ from live
For the latter can talk and connive.
But the former? Deceased,
Lacks a heartbeat, at least,
And won't move when you say, "Gimme five."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Cytherea, the goddess, may be a
Fine source for a lover's idea,
But she can't guarantee a
Complete panacea
If the guy should contract gonorrhea.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
That there heifer's as thin as a rail.
Flesh her out till her bulk's off the scale.
Fatted bovine allure
Ain't quite right for couture,
But at auction it's not known to fail.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Dephlegmation's a process of note
Once defined in a word, and I quote:
"Concentration." It's true.
It has nothing to do
With the process of clearing one's throat.

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
When Jason's friend Jay moved away,
He'd not see him for many a day.
Now that Jay has moved near,
(This is touching!) it's clear:
Through adjacency, Jason sees Jay.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
There is padding inside of this tank,
So the air seems quite stale, to be frank.
But the crash pads will aid
If we're caught in a raid
And get bumped—the designers we'll thank.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Is that 007 so hot?
As a spy, does he score?  Yeah, a lot!
Me, I'm 006.
I'm a flop with the chicks.
You would think I'd be suaver.  (I'm not.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
You have made me bananas! That's it!
When that flesh is unzipped, I'm a twit.
Will you let the taste linger
Or just slip me the finger
And then make like a banana and split?

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Take my word, and be visceral-wise:
If the thing you are trying to prise
Is the food from last night
That's stuck a bit tight,
Eccoprotics are what I advise.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Belayed on a pin, the rope's fast,
So the sail stays aloft on the mast.
The belaying pin's whacked
If the ship is attacked
And the swabs begin shouting, "Avast!"

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
See those thunderheads up in the sky,
While down here it continues so dry?
Silver iodide's needed—
To get those clouds seeded—
Not a cabbage patch, floating miles high!

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Here's the plan when your hunger attacks:
Sun-dried grapes make your tummy relax.
They're an energy burst;
You should reach for them first —
They're the best raisin d'etre for snacks.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Many months now I've dreamed as I've slumbered
Of weeks going by unencumbered.
Since Gregorian sages
Put digits on pages,
My calendar's days appear numbered.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Lisbon coffee's a minimal charge.
"Even cheaper in Rio," says Marge.
So let's hear a Bravo!
The lowly centavo
Makes sense when your bills are too large.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
You can work for your room and your board—
You'll earn board wages. Cut wood (a cord),
Or start fixing the roof!
Don't be lazy; don't goof—
Food and shelter will be your reward.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
Why are there—I've pondered the reason—
Different names for the very same season?
You'd think I'd remember,
Come end of September,
Fall and autumn are equally pleasin'.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I admit without any apology
That weather affects physiology.
When it's cloudy and rains,
I feel blue and have pains:
It is called biometeorology.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
I once was an intern, in training
As a medic, lived in; it was draining.
Internship complete,
Now an extern. How sweet!
I live out. You won't hear me complaining.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
At Eastertide, Christians rejoice
At the raising of Jesus. They voice
Their love for their Savior
With churchly behavior,
And my wife says, "You're going." No choice.

limerick_list.author: Quickbeam
limerick_list.text:
If a bev'rage or chemical firm should
Suggest mixing something with wormwood,
The instructions would state
Simply "absinthiate,"
Which defines it as no other term would.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When I'm weaving straw baskets, I yearn
To achieve just the right sort of turn,
So I sweat and I toil
When I'm making a coil
Like the circinal frond of a fern.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our art teacher figured, supposingly,
That our model was feckless. She'd dozingly
Dropped her jaw in a snore.
"You don't work here no more.
There's the door!" roared our tutor disposingly.

limerick_list.author: Dottie
limerick_list.text:
The French have just held an election.
Those not born there have cause for reflection.
Their future's less rosy
With Nico Sarkozy—
La France has a change of direction.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Afric francolin's main claim to fame:
The spurred ankles, bared neck. It's fair game
And resembles a partridge.
Son, fetch me a cartridge,
Load up, cock the trigger, take aim...

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The grain that we call durum wheat
Is, because it's so healthful to eat,
Held in highest regard.
From the Latin for "hard"
Comes the name of this high-protein treat.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan M. Guberman
limerick_list.text:
On a night with no moon, deadly black,
Something sinister looks for a snack.
No mosquito or leech
Is the cause of that screech,
But the bloodsucking count who's named Drac.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Grandma Dotty fed birds in the park.
She believed she was safe after dark:
"I can tell, in the wood
Folks are basically good."
Her acceptingness made her a mark.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
We were buffing our favorite piece
When Dad said, "Life's about elbow grease":
Of the mind, of the heart —
Work it in, do your part.
The rewards will be sweet, so don't cease.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Sardines complained, "Don't try to fence us,
You've gone wrong with your count, don't condense us,
For to put in that tin
Our whole shoal is a sin!
Yes. You've just taken leave of your census."

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
A small bell made of two metal cones,
The agogo's not used for its tones,
But, percussively, to
Add some style in a few
Latin/African musical zones.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
When I polish the floor, I will buff
It. Exerting, I puff and I huff
At the gym till I gleam,
And my bod gets esteem
'Cause I'm buff—surely not a cream puff.

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
They are cropped pants to some, or capris,
With your ankles exposed to the breeze.
But I think it's a shame
That their colorful name
Isn't used.  Call them clamdiggers, please.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Hey, let's do bouncy-bouncy," I said
To my wife, but my words were misread
By our children who heard.
Now the sex is deferred
As we visit a bounce house instead.

limerick_list.author: Doug Aldridge
limerick_list.text:
If the veins of a leaf have their start
At its petiole, staying apart
Till they fuse at the tip
(Side by side through the trip),
They are acrodrome—so says my chart!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
"So is that what you call a disease
That's presenting with symptoms like these?"
Asked the patient in shock
Of her dubious doc,
For whom acrisy led to unease.

limerick_list.author: Blind Pig
Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Peking Palace Online seems auspicious;
Ooh, a duck roll! I'll bet that's delicious.
But my clicking reveals
Just a mallard on wheels.
I've been duckrolled! This prank is pernicious!

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
Delalande, a biologist, mocks
The huge ears of a bug-eating fox.
"Like a bat's," he declares,
And bemusedly stares.
"And with those he wears formal black socks?"

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
The canonical form, we agree,
Is the way an equation should be:
It's a standard that's used
So that no one's bemused,
Such as y = mx + c.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Our new house mother, lately installed,
Has examined our lives; she's "appalled."
She's informed the whole dorm
That she's bent on reform.
"Custos Morum," she wants to be called.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Said the doc when I went for a checkup,
"Take your clothes off."  I thought, "What the heck?"  Up
I stood to take leave.
(I'm not freakin' naïve.
ENTs only deal with the neck up.)

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
There's a fable that's told by the locals
Of a Grecian whose name was Androcles
And the thorn he could tweeze
Thanks to fine spectacles
With split lenses; we call them bifocals.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Kiwi candy store owner Pat Gish
Says, "New Zealand is famous for fish.
There's a chocolate type
That lives up to all hype.
It's as boneless and sweet as you'd wish!"

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
"I see that you cannot conceive
Of my plans for you, so please believe
That this present, dear Adam,
Is now your new Madam.
Merry Christmas," spake God. (Enter Eve)

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Came assembler or 2GL next:
Now your code can be entered as text—
Though it may look like Greek
If you're not a sleek geek,
And an error will still leave you vexed.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Imagine the plight of Paul Getty:
His guests all considered him petty,
For a payphone was all
They could use for a call,
With a coin box (just pass that machete).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Epic chansons de geste laud heroic
Adventures of men, staunch and stoic,
Like dauntless Sir Roland
Who roams high- and lowland
For his king.  They seem paleozoic!

limerick_list.author: Tom Foolery
limerick_list.text:
When a habit just cannot be kicked,
To surrender oneself's to addict.
It's a verb full of blame,
For describing the shame
Of the habits the other guy's picked.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
What's it mean to allotropize?  Change
In a physical-property range.
But in substance?  No, no.
(This means elements, so
Don't apply it to humans; that's strange.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
George Frazier made World Series news,
Though I'd not want to be in his shoes.
Now for losses he's tied.
Still, he'd honestly tried,
While the other guy wanted to lose.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The crossrow was used to display
ABC's in a cruciform way.
Symbols writ, not in lines,
But in cross-shaped designs:
Superstition — not practiced today.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
By the door in a Tokyo bar
Stands a man with a Turkish cigar.
See, he's not from Japan—he
Is Azerbaijani.
He caught the wrong plane in Dakar.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
There was a musician named Amber
Who played the viola da gamba
In such a bad way
That she heard people say,
"Her fingers—they just seem to clamber."

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
Should you find, as you frolic and play,
That your head has detached, rolled away,
Then go fetch it! Your story,
Now bloody and gory,
Will end if you wait. Don't delay!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When the grasshopper calls with a chirr,
I never know what to infer.
I am wondering: is it
A plea for a visit?
A him-insect courting a her?

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
If you climb out a window before
The damn gatherer knocks at the door,
You will bear the whole brunt
Of the subsequent hunt.
Hunter-gatherers, well, they're hard-core

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
When your vermiform thingie's infected,
Better hope it's not long undetected.
It is known as appen-
dicitis; that's when
Your appendix must be disconnected.

limerick_list.author: FlippingMackerel
limerick_list.text:
Not a vase in good shape could be found.
Children crase things; they're rash; they astound.
Fragile objects can break,
Splinter, crack, by mistake—
Just get broken—when kids are around.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Inscribe circle in delta, near done.
That's the  Fano plane you have begun.
Now connect center points
To their angular joints—
Seven lines, with three points on each one.

limerick_list.author: Jim Vincent
limerick_list.text:
A factored expression is split
Into parts, which when multiplied knit
Back together again.
But do not use a pen
Since it's math (or that's maths to a Brit).

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
If something is crackly, it's brittle
Or crisp, and when crushed just a bit'll
Make sharp, snapping sounds;
Many kids this astounds,
And they'll play with it more than a little.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm at Hahvahd. My life was bucahlic
Till I tumbled to elephant gahlic.
Now I faht and I reek
From this wrongly named leek —
That pachyderm term is symbahlic.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
As a feminist, sometimes I rail
Against men who are hoping we fail
To achieve full equality;
They deride us with jollity,
Maintaining we're just antimale.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
As a method of knotting my tie,
I choose four-in-hand—simple, that's why.
Chuck your eighty-five ways
To do neckwear displays.
 I'm an all-of-my-days "schoolboy" guy.

limerick_list.author: Rose Nunez
limerick_list.text:
He ordered those pills for auxesis
So his wife wouldn't use a prosthesis.
Though augmented in size,
It neglected to rise,
So he boned up on psychokinesis.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Playing handball, Jack felt a sharp whack
As the ball hit his spine with a crack.
Now he's racked with neuralgia
And cramping—dorsalgia—
A whopping great pain in the back.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Excarnificate writers of verse.
Wicked limericists, masters of terse!
Tear the flesh off their bones;
Cut it off with sharp stones —
All the mischief they make is much worse.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
In the Andes, the heat is a killer.
Lest my beard make me sweat, I keep stiller.
There's a fan on my hat:
A small rodent who's sat
There to swish his thick tail — my chinchilla.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
The function of each contour feather
Is to mould a bird's shape, which shows whether
It is able to fly
Like the eagle, or lie
Well concealed like the grouse in the heather.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Prohibition was given a try,
But Americans drank on the sly.
When the law was undone
And abolishment won,
All the wets said, "Here's mud in your eye!"

limerick_list.author: jollierelm
limerick_list.text:
Alsike, a species of clover,
Differs from Red, which is mauver.
It's whiter than White,
Though equal in height.
Zigzag is much more bent over.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It's an old-fashioned word, but I try
To make use of this verb: I envie,
Yes, I strive, I compete
With the man in the street
To be most obsolete—God knows why.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My wife's lovers were only a fling,
She assures me (to lessen the sting).
But then I found out
What that word's all about.
To a doctor my wife I will bring.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
Sages say fortune favors the brave.
Is your brainstorm a "Boo!" or a rave?
Will you sit idly by
When fate winks its eye?
It takes courage to catch the next wave.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I seldom receive any mail
From regions we call arctogaeal.
Could take months—four or five—
For the mail to arrive,
Or delivery might simply fail.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
A blintz is a crepe that is made
With a filling of cheese, then sautéed.
While Russians would deem
That it needs sour cream,
The French much prefer it flambéed.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
A bibliographer's someone who aims
To keep track of the books and the names
Of the authors who wrote them
(So others can quote them)
In order, so Boehm's before James.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Alert! Quick—get out, leave the room!
If a bomb does explode with a boom,
Let's hope everyone's clear,
'Cause if not, then I fear
That the boom will create a big tomb.

limerick_list.author: paulthompson
limerick_list.text:
When you bring home the bacon, you strain
To support the adored ball and chain.
If you leave out the bacon
(If I'm not mistaken)
Bring home means "make perfectly plain".

limerick_list.author: alkahuna
limerick_list.text:
Lots of poems here, but none yet on doodle,
Or poodle, or noodle, or strudel.
We lack more than two-thirds
Of all possible words,
Yet may someday complete the caboodle.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Alagoas, a state in Brazil,
Is a place where the gals love the thrill
Of the sambas they dance,
While the guys find romance
In the "beautiful game" and its skill.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
Conformism seems too conventional,
A stance that can be unintentional.
This way looks so boring—
Eschewing exploring—
So hidebound, and so one-dimensional.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
You've decided to take off some weight,
So you skimped on your breakfast at eight;
Then attenuate light,
But at noon lost the fight
When you saw yourself eat and inflate.

limerick_list.author: Wattlebird
limerick_list.text:
The crickets is slang, so I'm told;
Awkward silence, you're out in the cold:
No reply when you talk,
Left alone as you squawk—
Just ignored and not part of the fold.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
Baking cookies, my wife always fails,
Though a lot of hard work it entails.
Seems she makes every batch
Of her cookies from scratch.
You can tell—they contain fingernails.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Uncle Earl (a bit of a squirrel)
Brought some screw anchors up to Aunt Shirl:
"Out of wall plugs, like these,
Make a coronet, please."
So now he is called Dook of Earl.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Yes, beer is brewed in Burton-on-Trent,
But gone for a burton is meant
To convey something's bust
(Died or broken). I trust
You will now understand its intent.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
The cheslip's a wood louse that seems
To invade my most horrible dreams,
But this ugly creation
Is just a crustacean
That dwells in dead wood along streams.

limerick_list.author: jsolomon
limerick_list.text:
It's amazing that nobody cared —
She walked 'round with her chest fully bared.
But in camp with the nude,
Clothes would be rather rude;
She disrobed at the gate as declared.

limerick_list.author: Giri
limerick_list.text:
Tom's habit of making allusions
Very often begets wrong conclusions.
It's a style he prefers.
His oblique speaking blurs
What he means and then causes confusions.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Here's a sign our economy's nuts,
And that someone from Congress has guts:
Now the light at the end
Of the tunnel, my friend,
Will be shut due to new budget cuts.

limerick_list.author: Chris Baker
limerick_list.text:
Accostable? That's my friend Jack,
He'll chat and then welcome you back.
For some help or a natter,
Especially the latter,
Choose him, as he does have the knack.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To our doorbell we'll soon say so long.
Something's terribly, horribly wrong.
It goes "Ding," but that's it.
Halfway through it will quit
Its binotonous call of "Ding-dong."

limerick_list.author: waterrocks and David
limerick_list.text:
Education should aim to enhance
Children's thinking. When given the chance,
Growing minds can be freed
From a church school's old creed.
Teach them wonder and truth — that's our stance.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A small, insignificant Greek
Is a Greekling. Is this word unique?
I have tried, but can't find
Other words so unkind
Coined to offer an ethnic critique.

limerick_list.author: natelevin
limerick_list.text:
An able reformer, Ms. Blatch—
Mother's zeal she endeavored to match.
With New York in the lead,
Women voters were freed,
And the right of the ballot they'd catch.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Heard of bitcoins? They're digital cash.
You can pay peer-to-peer, in a flash,
With no regs and no rules.
Is this wampum for fools?
What happens if mining pools crash?

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
"Been injured?" the billboard shouts out.
"Call the office of Weisel & Flout.
We'll sue 'em, pursue 'em,
And thoroughly screw 'em…"
Some barratrous touts, without doubt.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Eatin' baccy, tomatoes, and bolls
(Those of cotton) are three of the roles
That the corn earworm fills
Till it pupates, which stills
All the thrills of its ravenous strolls.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Mom and Dad, please accept my dignation,
For I honor your acts of formation
From my first day till now:
You're great parents!  And how!
Awesome worthiness needs celebration.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
When it came, there was no time to hide:
Our mortality rode on that tide.
It claimed thousands of lives,
But our spirit survives
As our terrors and panic subside.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
There were times when my life saw me stray.
In review with St. Peter today,
I made known what I'd change.
He said, "God won't arrange
For a do-over, son.  Better pray."

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
Is your welding gas leaking, aflame?
Run like hell, while you "Fire!" exclaim.
This was wisdom of old,
But the fire, I'm told,
Now the flashback arrestors will tame.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
There's a misunderstanding, I'm sensing.
Yes, it's true, I'm an expert at fencing,
But I use posts and rails,
Held together by nails—
Not a sword when to fence I'm commencing.

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
A large Indian stork, this bird likes
To eat putrefied carrion—yikes.
For the adjutant bird,
Life near water's preferred;
With a soldierly gait this bird hikes.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
The bloke at my local bodega
Was vague, though he could have been vaguer.
(I was selling him seed.)
"How much grain do you need?"
"Coupla' bushels—about a fanega."

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Concentration we measured in class.
Our sad classmate (insolvent, alas)
Tested one-tenth of normal:
Decinormal (more formal).
Can this chemistry student still pass?

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I am known in the trade as an eeler.
I catch eels I won't sell to Will Wheeler
As Will pays not a lot
For each eel that I've caught;
Will's the wiliest eel wheeler-dealer.

limerick_list.author: David Franks
limerick_list.text:
If you knock off of work around five,
Here's two pubs where a guy might revive:
The Frog Hair is fine,
And The Ivy's divine.
But steer clear of The Swan—it's a dive.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
"Only proper," said Dad, "that I share
Out the coins, till the box is left bare.
As you've all equal claim,
You will each get the same.
I'll make sure that it's done fair and square."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Self-destructive, Tom climbed into bed,
Broke an artery, bled—now he's dead.
What a mess he had left.
Now his family's bereft:
"How we wish he'd used poison instead!"

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
A dog-leg, when out on the links,
Is a fairway that bends or has kinks.
It can also be found
On your average hound,
Where there's one at each corner, methinks.

limerick_list.author: Dixon Wragg
limerick_list.text:
The closeted Reverend Haggard
Was a vile, hypocritical blackguard,
And through each passing year,
He denounced all things queer.
Now the scandal has left his flock staggered.

limerick_list.author: snakelocks
limerick_list.text:
If you 'anker to fill up your flask,
Park your butt while I find the right cask.
You punch'n your order,
I'll go to the gorda.
This is more than a wee firkin task.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Many systems of worship, we find,
Have revering the earth on their mind.
They're as earth worship known
And we find most will own
That their roots are in early mankind.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Drawing blood, in its literal sense,
Speaks to acts that make bleeding commence.
As a metaphor, though,
With no gore and no flow,
It refers to a verbal offense.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
His behavior is sinful and evil;
His actions engender upheaval.
He's wedded to revelry,
Which he spices with devilry.
Such malfeasance won't merit reprieval.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
All your theories are widely dismissed.
Your predictions fall flat. Please desist!
Clouds can not tell you when
We'll be shaking again.
"Earthquake weather" just doesn't exist!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I have seen with my own naked eye—
This I swear, cross my heart, hope to die—
What? A dragon for real!
Come outside; here's the deal:
See? There's Draco—way up in the sky.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A jellyfish group is a bloom.
That's a swarm where, together, they loom.
Since you know that these things
Can have poisonous stings,
When encountering blooms, give 'em room.

limerick_list.author: EdRush
limerick_list.text:
The angler tells tales of the size
Of the fish that have met their demise.
Credulity stretches
As Fisherman fetches
More beer to embellish his lies.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
There's rage in each well-chosen word;
Every syllable sings to the herd.
She's fomenting rebellion
And bedlam, that hellion.
Can't ignore her—the bitch will be heard.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
"I'm accepting all comers," said he,
"I can win any fight as you'll see."
Then a hulk came along,
Quickly proving him wrong.
He whined, "How could this happen to me?"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Andretti, supressing a smirk'll
Admit any lead-footed jerk'll
Earn fans driving 'round
And around and around
And around and around in a circle.

limerick_list.author: sl8ofhand
limerick_list.text:
When their power's unbalanced and checkless,
Those in office, our leaders, get reckless.
If in check they're not kept,
Some will turn out inept,
If not foolhardy, feeble, and feckless.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
I aspire to higher acclaim.
My aspiration?  That you know my name.
I'm hardly a tyrant—
Just a budding aspirant—
But stay out of the way of my fame.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
In the wurst-eating race, I was first
Since I'd practiced and drilled and rehearsed.
I ate wurst after wurst
'Til I thought I might burst—
Then I did: what went down was reversed.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Bombyliidae: bee flies. They buzz,
Sip on nectar, wear gold-and-black fuzz.
But as larvae, they munch
Larval namesakes — a bunch
Of debased, parasitical scuzz.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When I'm home from my job I repair
To my beautiful butterfly chair,
Where I rest in its sling,
And I don't do a thing.
Call me lazy? A slug? I don't care!

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
O mother, please don't be distressed,
For your baby's young life is still blest.
Yes, the medics have said
Rising blood cell count (red)
Means an op won't be needed, just rest.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
"You've confused things," the barman explained:
"The container for what is contained.
Ask for beer—that's okay;
But a bottle—no way!
I would give you one already drained."

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
At the Limerick zoo, right at three,
I shall meter, I've promised, for tea.
But she is not around—
Love runs always aground.
And an ape sticks his tongue out at me!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Her stained dress had the most evidentiary
Weight in that "Crime of the Century".
Since Exhibit A-3
Bore his DNA, he
Got life in a state penitentiary.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A man and his dog in a barque
That was cut from a log in the park
May by night try to sneak,
Quite unheard, up the creek,
If the dog doesn't bark in the dark.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
God's elect should be pretty darn sure
That their souls are untainted and pure,
That their predestination
Means certain salvation.
Who's elect? God's released no brochure.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Here's the graveplot of secretive Gary,
Who, with weapon concealed, was quite chary;
But the chain of Pam's locket
Got caught in his pocket —
The upshot resulting was scary.

limerick_list.author: Dottie
limerick_list.text:
If your nose is a freak anatomical
And its size has become astronomical,
I dare say, for your money
That's not very funny,
But for me it's exceedingly comical.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
To expediate means to make haste,
To lay each obstruction to waste,
To affirm wheels are greased,
To get hold-ups released,
To ensure as the winner you're placed.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Those swimmers would never have drowned
Had the lifeguard kept looking around
Circumspectly, with care,
As she perched on her chair,
Getting beautifully, evenly browned.

limerick_list.author: Dottie
limerick_list.text:
To blow the bassoon is an art,
And the curtal's quite tricky to start.
So how do they differ?
The curtal reed's stiffer—
Needs more of a burp than a fart.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
At the head of this column, alone,
See me chiselling stone, in the zone.
And behold, here unfolding,
Cymatium (moulding)—
The classical trimming I hone.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
Serenading a girl? Play a tune.
Strum dolente, your gaze on the moon.
For that sorrowful tone,
Universally known,
Sometimes makes a small romance balloon.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
The fur of a witch's pet cat,
A bowler or stovepipe top hat,
A liquorice stick
Or the heart of Old Nick:
Yes, coal-black is blacker than that.

limerick_list.author: Comicoffee
limerick_list.text:
Ahem! May I have your attention?
Don't sit on those cacti. I'll mention
This now, 'fore you find
A quite tender behind
With more pricks than a lawyers' convention.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm Italian.  My teacher, named Sonya,
Tutors English in Jersey (Leonia).
"For untruths," she said, "Tony,
Say full of baloney."
That's wrong!  Sonya's full of bologna.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
You're a vagabond, aimlessly rootless,
And your effort's consistently fruitless.
Still, you never say die,
As you bootlessly try
What is pointless and stupidly bootless.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To write comedy takes a fine touch,
But professionals charge way too much,
So they crowdsource the writing
And make it exciting,
Then "pay" folks with magnets and such.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
We nosedived, our plane twisty-twirly.
Said the pilot, above all the hurly:
"This emergency landing
Might flop; notwithstanding,
We still should be touching down early!"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Our daughters behave and excel,
While our sons often put us through hell.
We don't coddle the males,
But just paddle their tails,
Since a caudal shellacking works well.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When you're snorkeling, you needn't look far.
An anemone, bright as a star—
An audacious actinia—
Will stick its barbs in ya.
